author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2018
review_content: Best. Game. Ever.I have two daughters, one whom has Apraxia of speech and the other who is a beginning reader. The pictures ensure that my younger daughter (with Apraxia) can still independently play, while it encourages both my children to read aloud the object. This game requires no adult help, so my daughters will literally spend hours playing this game together. It is super sturdy game with thick, sturdy, double sided cardboard bingo cards and the text and pictures on the yellow “chips” have no scratching or fading from frequent overuse; we do have problems sticking the discarded yellow chips back in on one side of the Zingo machine if it’s not placed in the slot *just so*, but I’m sure it’s from an overzealous preschooler and not the manufacturer. This game is now my go-to gift for any birthday party we are invited to and my girls are always requesting to pack it to bring with to friends and families houses. Buy it. Buy it now. You won’t regret it!
title: Buy. It. Now.

author: No No
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2013
review_content: When I read in the description that the game had 72 tiles, I assumed 72 different words; after all, it is marketed for children in pre-K to 1st grade. The description should mention that there are only 24 different words (three tiles per word).The words included are as follows: AND, COME, FOR, HERE, MY, SAID, THE, THREE, WE, WHERE, ARE, HAVE, OUR, SHE, THERE, THEY, WENT, WHAT, WHO, ME, IN, TWO, NOW, WANT.
title: Only 24 different words.

author: Peace & Joy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2018
review_content: My boys (4 & 6) love game night but my wife and I were tiring of Candyland.  Zingo has been a great alternative.  I would just recommend one change:  have some Zingo cards with the actual numbers on them.  I know they're trying to reinforce counting, but some of the objects on the card they are supposed to count are spaced too closely together and get confusing for little one to count.  We just made our own cards with numbers to get around this.
title: A great game for 6 and up.  Younger one might need home-made number cards.

author: Miran S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2017
review_content: I love all Zingo games; I now have three of them. I use them with my students with autism, ages 6-8. It is a great language tool. It helps with fine motor skills. Students have to put the pieces back into the slot if no one has the item. They have to use a pincher grip to push it in and there is a little tension so they have to push a little bit. We had to teach them to put them in correctly, but they caught on quick. I am not sure what it is but the act of pushing the game piece in is reinforcing and they love to do it. This is great for my kids who have weakness in their hands. It also helps with motor planning. Students also take turns being the number caller. This allows for independence in game playing. Students learn their numbers, identifyinghow many objects are in a group, addition using pictures, and number words. A lot can be taught with this one little game.
title: A must have for special needs classrooms!

author: Eleni
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2019
review_content: This game is perfect for my 4.5 year old that is in speech. He has apraxia and this is doing wonders on helping him practice his words in a timely fashion. Also, learning how to take turns and that you don’t always win!
title: Would recommend

author: Tim Showalter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2017
review_content: My kids love this. We got our first set as a gift. I bought this one as a spare because it was quickly clear that my 4-year-old twins were going to destroy the original set. That's OK. The game held up well, and the tiles are easy for kids to lose. The "Zinger" mechanism works very well; we have rarely had problems with it, and it works for the kids playing independently. But the new set came with a couple surprises. It's 7-player, 78-tiles instead of 6-player 72-tiles. So the cards are different, which is a surprise. But not a big problem.What was a surprise is that my new set is short 2 tiles. I got only 76. (If you care to do an inventory, there should be 3 of every tile.) So I'm a little short on spares.For small kids, this is a great toy, but I think the quality control could be improved.
title: Fun for small kids, mechanism works well, beware of missing tiles

author: Brandy M
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2017
review_content: Lots of fun!Pros:1) fun way to learn sight words. It is always good for us to take school work out of the equation,  and just make it fun!2) the format is easy and keeps the game compact and neat. We have the traditional zing as well, and this is great. If you get a card you don't need, simply slip it back into the dispenser using the sits on the top.3) the game is 100% words,  so kids learn what the sight words are. There are some tiny symbols, but not really pictures.Cons:No big cons. We love zingo games. The only thing that makes it 4 stars instead of 5 is that I wish there were more sight words in the game, or they had two card and tile sets. Not a deal breaker, but something to note.
title: simply fun!

author: elizabeth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2017
review_content: this is one of the only toys I have ever bought for my kid that I actually enjoy playing with with her.  she loves it because she gets a kick out of the dispenser contraption and she loves the individual attention of playing a game with adults.  the fact that it is so simple to play (don't need to read any directions) and isn't mind-numbingly boring for adults is what makes this the perfect toy.  my child is 3.5 and I wish I had bought it for her sooner, but she can play it easily at her current age.
title: the perfect game for your toddler

author: Sunny Shopper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2020
review_content: Ok for a little practice but not that useful.  Not really worth $25.The game has ONLY 24 WORD tiles.  I read in the description that it had 72 tiles, but didn’t realize there are 3 of each (which I understand for the game purpose if you’re playing with multiple people but they need to provide more tiles with more words).My child just completed Kindergarten and they were expected to read a list of 100 words.  He needs more practice on some so a classmate’s parent recommended this game.  But these tiles only represent 1/4 of the words he needs to know to start first grade (and we haven’t played yet for me to see if they are the words he knows already or not...)Also, the cards have TOO MANY PICTURE CLUES.  This makes it easier for the child to use the picture as a reminder/prompt versus truly recall/read the word, which is the point of sight words.  There should be another version on the back of the cards with words only.  This would help because when assessed in Kindergarten they have 3 seconds to read the word to prove they know it (no picture clue or time to sound it out).Another idea would be to sell a “refill kit” if you already have the original Zingo (which we really liked so this is sad!). I keep the tiles in a snack-size zippered plastic bag to prevent them from getting lost, so I could just use the same red dispenser if the refill kit came with tiles and cards only.  This would make the product cheaper and easier to package/ship.  And if they couldn’t add more than 72 tiles in one set, they could offer different refill sets with more words.
title: Not that useful - Only 24 words & cards have picture clues

author: Traci M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2014
review_content: At the time of this review I taught "regular" first grade students.  My students were on various levels (Pre-K through 2nd) when it came to reading.  One of the most difficult tasks of teaching can be making learning fun.  I found this game on Amazon and thought it might be a good addition to my small group teaching time (after a structured lesson).  The result?  ALL of my students fell in love with this game.  They would often ask to play it during their small group reading time if we had time left at the end of the lesson.  There are two sides to each card; however, even my students who were below grade level could use the "harder" side of the card.  The key part of this is to have the students read the word (or try to read the word) before getting the word chip.  Even though they are sight words I found it essential to help the student try to figure out the word to ensure success.  Rather than only get three in a row I often played the game where the entire card had to be filled.  At the end of the game I would always reward the students with a pencil, eraser, ticket, etc... whether or not they won.  That avoided anybody feeling like they lost.  It didn't ever delete the motivation to play because each student still wanted to win.If you want to make learning fun, try this game.
title: My Students LOVED This Game

author: OCmom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2019
review_content: I bought this game for my girls when they were 5 & 3, 13 years ago... we used it for years! Now we use it with younger cousins! We are keeping our game for grandchildren, but I bought another to gift to my niece who has Downs’ Syndrome, because she loves playing it, and the concept is easy enough for her to grasp with special needs, yet still a challenge for her. We have a great time playing this with adults and children of all ages in our family! It is like bingo, but you match the picture of the tile to the picture on your board. Also, there is a cool device to deal the tiles so that everyone can play, even the dealer! It can be played with 2 people or many more! I highly recommend this game if you are looking for a game that is inclusive for many different capability levels! You can all play, and have a great time without feeling like someone didn’t get a fair shot! Also, it helps kids learn. So, any educational game is a plus in my book!
title: Great game for kids & adults of all ages & capability levels/ including special needs children!

author: Jess
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
review_content: I absolutely love this game.  It assists my 3 year old with recognizing various items and also starts with sight words.  It is an added bonus that he loves yelling bingo!  The red cards are more competitive and nice for older ages.  The green cards have less duplication so theyre less competitive.  We try to stay on the green side with my 3 year old.  Id definitely recommend this item.
title: Great for toddlers

author: Amzn customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2019
review_content: Not sure if this product is counterfeit but the instructions clearly state repeatedly that the sight words zingo has two sided tiles for easier and harder play. Mine are uniformly yellow, and printed the same word front and back. Clearly this is not as good as a game with two levels of play...and worse it’s inconsistent with its own instructions which makes me think it is maybe a lower quality knock off / counterfeit?
title: Not sure if counterfeit...?

author: Jellybean
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2015
review_content: My parents got the original picture Zingo for our 4 year old daughter and it's been a huge hit.  When I saw that there was a word building version, we had to have it for her as well.  There's no setup required like punching out pieces or assembling anything, it's ready to go when you take it out of the box.  I like that there are two sides to the cards so younger children can play the easy side and older children and adults can play the harder side to make play a little more evenly matched.  The tiles are sturdy plastic so you don't have to worry about them bending them or ruining them by getting them wet or anything, plus they're double sided, so no need to put them into the Zinger 'right side up'.  The letters on the tiles and cards are also colored red for vowels and black for consonants.  This makes it easy to explain to younger kids that on the 'easy' side of the cards, you need 2 black letters and 1 red letter for each word.  The 'Zinger' is the hard plastic house that the tiles live in and are dispensed from.  The top slides easily forward and back to drop two tiles into the little grooves each time.  Then you slide the tiles back into as lot in the top if not needed with a satisfying little click sound.  Another nice feature is all the pieces fit easily back in the sturdy game box without taking anything apart!  Our 4 year old picked up the game quickly even though she's averse to spelling and reading and it gets her to sound out the words on her own because she wants to beat Mommy!
title: We love Zingo!

author: J. S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
review_content: I got this for my daughter, who is in kindergarten, who is really struggling with learning her sight words and does not enjoy flash cards.  We are not to the point to play the game as instructed, instead we are just popping the plastic chips out of the word dispenser and reading them together and then trying to find the match on our cards.  My 4 year old is also joining in, once again more as a matching game as she can't read these words yet either.  They like sliding the word dispenser and popping the plastic chips back in if there's no match.  There are six cards and all are printed front and back for the choice of twelve cards (the game says the green side is less competitive and the red side is more competitive), and there are nine words on each card.  Here are my reasons for 4 stars:  The sight words that are reviewed are as follows: and, are, come, for, have, here, in, me, my, now, our, said, she, the, there, they, three, two, want, we, went, what, where, who.  Being there are only 24 words, and in kindergarten (at least at my daughter's school) she is learning 50, so I wish there were more words to learn in the game (like the word "she" is played but not the word "he")  Also the word "she" is only on one out of the twelve cards; it seems that some words are focused on more than others.  So while I still find this game is helpful, the girls find it fun, and it was very easy to set-up and learn, I do wish it was more in-depth.
title: lots of fun but could include more sight words

author: Dana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2018
review_content: We've owned zingo for two days now. Roughly 67 rounds later I think it's safe to say my son, almost 4, loves it. I have nothing but good things to say... the tile dispenser runs smoothly, the game is simple and fun for preschoolers. With zero learning curve, he enjoyed it straight out of the box.I understand from my sister, whose kids are now 14 & 11, that the game has been improved since early versions with the picture on both sides of the tile, so no blanks are dispensed or extra time spent ensuring everything is face up when resetting the game.
title: He plays again and again and again and again

author: Brian B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2020
review_content: High quality. The zingo machine is easy enough for my 5 year old to slide by her self. The only thing is that the sight word zingo is too hard for my 5 year old. I wish it had simple starter words like: to, in, etc. The words are big words like: come, these, etc. They are advanced sight words best suited for a 1st grader or up. I wish they had the simple two letter words in there instead of long advanced words. They claim the green side is easier but both sides are equally hard. I have to dock two stars for the extreme lack of simple beginner words. If I had a child in 1st or second grade it would be perfect.
title: Not beginner sight words

author: Monique
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
review_content: This game has been great for our 4-6 year olds who are learning to read. My only issue is the letter I. My children keep sounding it out as an L. A couple of extra lines with a red Sharpie fixed that.We have changed the rules to suit them for now. They grab the letter, put it where they want, and then sound out the word. We ask if it is a real word, and if not, they try again.
title: Change the letter I.

author: Amariepeace
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
review_content: I really enjoy this game for a few reasons, which follow:-My kids love playing it- It's teaching my youngest (3) to pay attention (he gets upset when he misses one but he's learning to pay closer attention, I feel like it's helping with his attention span)- It's teaching them object recognition as well as word recognition - When they get an image I have them spell the letters and say the word.- When they have a space that matches a shown tile we have them ask politely for the tile, after a few times playing this way it has really helped with getting them to sit still during gameplay and it also enforces using manners when requesting something (please) and receiving something (thank you).I deducted one star because sometimes it dispenses 2 tiles out of the same space and gets stuck - this is annoying and slows down the game because then I have to fidget with it to get the tiles out. Not a deal-breaker just annoying.
title: Fun game and can be great learning game

author: Jean
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2019
review_content: This game comes with a plastic dispenser for 2 plastic board images and plastic coated paper sheets to play Bingo.I have reread the instructions numerous times to see if there is something to this game that I'm missing.Considering it's a $19.99 game at Amazon, and a WHOPPING $48.99 at Walmart,I  expected a fantastic kids game....This is ridiculous-unless someone can tell me what I'm missing, this needs to be researched about the price ,andclaims to being one of the top games of 2018. I'm open to others opinions.
title: This is Bingo-overrated with a Z !

author: Jennifer L. Tyner
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2016
review_content: Zingo is one of the greatest games for young children! It teaches them patience while waiting a turn, as well as numbers, letters, sight words/pictures, and it is very easy to operate. I have 3 kids 2, 4, 6 - and they all love playing this game together. My 2 year old does lose interest by the end, but that is expected for her age. She does have a fun time for the first 15-20 minutes though. My boys think this is the greatest game though, and it is one you can play with the whole family.
title: Zingo is one of the greatest games for young children

author: Kim N.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
review_content: This game was a gift for an almost 4 year old.  Its a great gift for a child to grow into.Pros:1. Child can match the words from the word chips to the pictures/words on the board, even if they don't know how to spell.2. A game that can go at any pace for any 4 year old and older.3. A great learning too for someone learning to read.4. Fun for anyone 4 years and older.5. Game is pretty sturdy and well made.  Boards could get bent up if someone tried to do that, but otherwise they are good quality.  Word chips are plastic and of good quality.No Cons!I would definitely recommend this game and buy again for a gift for someone.
title: Great game for a child to grow into....

author: Jeannette Reding
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
review_content: I bought this for my three year old grandson on October 23 to get a jump on purchasing Christmas gifts. The return window was November 24. The game does not function correctly. The small plastic cards jam in the dispenser. I guess I won't buy any early Christmas gifts through Amazon ever again. It has been a total waste.
title: The cards jam in the dispenser making it impossible to use.

author: Kansas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2018
review_content: Bought this game to play with our 5 year old granddaughter.  The concept is great, and we are enjoying playing the game.  However, the dispenser for the word tiles is a piece of junk.  The tiles get jammed and are impossible to stack in straight.  We resorted to putting the word tiles in a bag and drawing them rather than using the faulty dispenser.  Very disappointed with that.
title: Dispenser is a piece of junk.

author: R. P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
review_content: Very nice concept - my 4.5 yrs old loves it and wants to play all the time. Giving only one star because of poor quality control. It came with a total of 78 tiles and 7 cards. While the tiles for green cards are complete, there are 6 tiles missing for the red cards -  a cat, a heart, a  dog, a ball, a kite, and a star. This means seven players can never play the red side (see the attached pictures)
title: missing tiles for red cards

author: keroleen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2018
review_content: We love this game! Works for my preschooler and toddler. They call the foot stinky toes which makes us laugh every time! Really helps with their vocabulary and my preschooler’s spelling and recognition of words.
title: Fun and educational!

author: Kelly Wynn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2020
review_content: Bought this game for my 2-year-old. Easy enough for her to play. We followed the instructions the first time we played, but now she just wants to throw the game pieces around. It's great for helping her identify the objects on the game pieces and matching. She likes the concept of the game just lacks the attention span to play right now.
title: Cute game!!

author: JOAM228
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
review_content: Got this for my almost 5 year old son. He loves playing it. It's a fun spin on bingo for little ones. He learns to identify words with pictures and increases focus by paying attention to the pieces he collects as he tries to complete his card and yell "Zingo." That's his favorite part. The only negative I have is that the pieces often come out in doubles or more and get stuck when trying to get them out. This makes it hard for little ones to play alone because they need adult help to fix that issue for them. I  learned of this game through a former employer about 12 years ago and that game also had this same issue. Disappointing to see they have not fixed that at this point.
title: Fun family game

author: SCheek
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2020
review_content: The box seems a little big for the game but that doesn’t matter so much as how much my boy loves this game. He played first when he was 4 but I waited a while to purchase our own game. He’s 5 now and still loves it!  He will play more than 4 rounds at a time if I’d sit with him. He is able to lead the game on his own because of how easy and intuitive it is. The parts are all safe to have around with my 10 month old, except the cards do get wrinkles if they’re chewed on. Perhaps plastic Zingo cards like what the little “call” cards are made of?  Plus, because there are a lot of “call” cards I can see how these might get spread out around the house and would not be fun to pick up after a while. Just a thought. Thankfully it’s not been a problem here.And thankfully there are no sounds or batteries to contend with.
title: A big hit!

author: Mary
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
review_content: Too basic, words too easy, not enough sight words, many are duplicates
title: Don’t buy it

author: JLaughlin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
review_content: I bought this game to play with my 4 and 8 year old sons hoping it would help with their reading. The game is like bingo. You get a card and you have to match the tiles to the pictures on your card. Maybe there are too many tiles but it seems like the same tiles always shows up and the game just drags looking for the last one. I also don't think my sons are looking at the words but looking at the pictures instead. Doubt I would buy this game again.
title: Ok game

author: Deebi27
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2020
review_content: As an educator, this is a great learning game. However after opening, two of each of the game piece would be enough. The extra could have been use for some more words. Between the three Dolch Sight Word lists for Pre-K - 1st grade there are 133 total sight words. This is a great way for kids to learn their sight words. Two (instead of 3) of each word set.I love this idea for the game, please make future words sets available to complete the full 133 wordsplaying pieces (2 of each word) for this great learning game!
title: Great and Even Better With All the Words for Pre-k to 1st Grade

author: Natalie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2018
review_content: I bought this one along with the other zingo’s for my four children. My 3 year old son absolutely loves this number one! He likes to play it by himself even. One of my favorite thing about this game is the game boards have the number with a picture of how many on one side. The other side is pictures you add to get the number. It’s. I’ve beciase my son is constantly counting or adding without knowing he is learning. I really recommend! His older sibling don’t mind playing this either
title: Great game! Learning without knowing.

author: Agata Bergstrom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2020
review_content: She says it's her favorite toy. Ever since she received it, we have to play it first thing in the morning right after she wakes up and then at least 3-4 more times during the day. It's great that it's fun for the whole family and not too boring for adults (as most toddler games are). It was her first competitive game and she had a hard time losing at first and would throw tantrums. But she quickly learned losing is part of the game, and while she still does her cute little dance to celebrate winning, she now keeps track and sometimes even deliberately lets me win now (!) because "I won three times in a row, now you win, mama". Such a great little social game with simple rules even 3 year olds can grasp.
title: My 3 year old is obsessed

author: YC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2020
review_content: Loving this game. Best gift ever. Was looking for a fun way to teach sight words during home schooling and this is a good supplement. I wished it had a few more words but the fact that my 5 yo wants to play this daily is amazing. We were bored of flash cards and online learning apps. I know there are other versions of this game so I'm going to be looking for those. This will teach a few basic words to help supplement your child's learning. It is not hard to play and only takes a few minutes so it keeps their attention. Good buy.
title: My 5 yo wants to play every day

author: Frugal Mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2019
review_content: Slider jams and 4 tiles come out. My preschool kids had a hard time with it. I had to return.
title: Slider jams and 4 tiles come out.

author: Christine S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
review_content: The Zingo games are simple yet fun. My only complaint is that occasionally the tiles stick when you slide it for the new pieces to pop out. With that said, it IS heavy plastic and durable, not cheaply made. I was concerned the tiles would start to wear out or fade but the game still looks new after many uses. Well made, great concept.
title: Durable fun learning game

author: Marie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2020
review_content: I used to play this while babysitting, approximately 12 years ago. I remembered enjoying it and bought it for my son as a christmas gift this year. The plastic is definitely less sturdy than it used to be and the "zinger" or whatever you call the tile dealer that came with ours does not work. The tiles are constantly jamming or it deals 2 at a time on each side. It was played with once on Christmas day. I got so frustrated with it that I boxed it up and put it away with plans to return it. I completely forgot about it and now it's too late. So fair warning, check yours when it arrives to make sure it works.
title: Defective? Check it before it's too late to return it.

author: Beez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2019
review_content: They are quite serious when they say K-1 grade.  Your child really needs to have letter sounds and fundamental spelling of simple words down before investing in this game.That said, it does a great job pointing out the importance of vowels vs. consonants -- even our pre-schooler picked up on the different tile colors.  Our kid does love this game and wants to play it....  She just isn't ready for it yet.  I look forward to being able to write a better review in a year or two because this was NOT the fault of the manufacturer..  I just thought the game was slightly different than what it turned out to be.
title: Great game for kids who know basic words.

author: J Fox
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2020
review_content: The red mechanism doesn’t work. Couldn’t get the top open so kids put each piece in the side one by one...so frustrating!!! Nice idea, but would recommend old fashioned bingo without the fancy device that doesn’t work.
title: Doesn’t work!!!

author: Dime Joi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2020
review_content: This is the greatest learning tool...I have 2 children with autism, intellectual disabilities, ADHD and 1 of them is also deaf, and this is a great learning tool in every way.  My deaf child is learning sign language and this helps, she learns to sign the pictures, and the youngest with autism-it helps him with memory.  He is shown the picture and has to tell what it is and how to spell it and they are his sight words for the day.  Spelling is going great with both children and now for the 4 year old...she is also learning with this game.  I love playing this game also...Great for the entire family.  I recommend this game for the entire family, friends and anyone who needs help with children education!
title: Great for all ages!

author: Anna C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2020
review_content: We bought this for our 4 year old daughter.  She loves it. The combination of pictures and words makes is easy so she can play with us or on her own with her friends. The only issue is that sometimes two tiles come out of one side, causing the whole thing to get stuck and not work.  We are able to fix it, but it's nearly impossible for our daughter to do it herself.  If looking for a completely independent game that can be used without adults, this would not be it.
title: Great way to make learning fun

author: Wanda
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2020
review_content: This is a great little game that is pretty quick to learn and play (a "round" only takes about 5 min. or so). My 3-year-old son loves it and wants to play it every day. As a bonus, he also likes putting away the "chips/markers" when the game is over. The game is overall very sturdy and well-made. Our "zinger" unit sometimes deposits more than 2 chips/markers at once, but it doesn't really impede our ability to play the game.
title: My 3-year-old son loves this game!

author: sueshire
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2017
review_content: Great game to play with little kids. I play with my grandkids, ages 6 and 4. Even the little 18 month old likes to pretend to play. Game is sturdy, pieces are well made. We had to make a rule that if you grab one that doesn't match your card, you have to lose a tile to keep the game civil.
title: Fun game

author: Sue Emanuel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2020
review_content: I bought this game for my 3-year-old granddaughter.  Even though it says ages 4 and up, she had no problem learning the game.  She had never played Bingo before but she loves this game.  Her 5-year-old brother and 2-year-old cousin also love it, although the 2-year-old does need some help.  Not everyone has the same pictures on their card, so the child needs to look at the yellow plastic piece and see if they need it or not.  If they do, they grab it.  Surprisingly, there hasn't been any fighting when someone didn't get the picture they need--I guess because they know there will be more chances as the game goes on.  As a parent/grandparent, I like that the game is not too long and that the concept was easy to understand.  Fill up your card and you win.  It goes fast enough that more than one round can be played and that gives the "loser" a chance to win.  The only complaint I have is that the plastic tray thing that dispenses the yellow pieces can sometimes jam so an adult needs to be monitoring it.
title: Great game for 3-year-old

author: Book Addict
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2020
review_content: Simple, easy, and clear game. We've played it once and will many times more, I think. However, IMHO, it falls short in two areas. 1 - all the tiles/letters are upper-case (which isn't mentioned on the product page), even though kids learn to read/spell using lower-case letters, because they're much more frequently used. 2 - less important, but storing the game and pieces apparently wasn't a priority. The box has no compartments and is way too big for the cards and dealer pieces. The boxes for my 3 Zingo games are all the same size, so perhaps it's a cost-savings, but it could have been a little better planned.
title: Great but for two things

author: Happy123456
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2017
review_content: Awesome game!  We play this game with my 8 year old son with autism (non-verbal) and we get to play it in many different ways.  He loves pressing down the little red mechanism that spits out the yellow cards.  We then make him say the objects on the cards before he can pick them up and place them on the zingo card.  Super fun game for him.
title: Autism friendly

author: Portland Mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2014
review_content: There are two ways to play.  One with matching numbers with the amount of items on the card.  Or matching numbers with addition problems on the card. Both ways are fun and educational.On the cards with "items"  the number word is also  present.  So the child can either count the items and match with the Arabic number or she can match the word with the number.On the cards with addition problems:  there are only items, so the child has to count the items and then match the number.It was okay.  I think having the written word on the cards added confusion once we flipped over to addition since before the child may just match word and  number.  And on the other side they have to match picture with number.  Though this may be a good thing if your child needs to work on understanding 1:1
title: Can be fun

author: Dave
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2020
review_content: BEST. GAME. EVER!!! we got this game last week after a friend kept recommending it to me. Ever since we received it, we have been having family game nights every night with my 4 year old. We play Zingo multiple times per night and he begs for more. The game is so easy to learn- my 4 year old picked it up just as fast as the adults did...and has even been beating us. It keeps him engaged and actually teaches him to recognize sight words and know what they say. We absolutely love this game! Great buy and worth the price. We will get a lot of use out of this.
title: Keeps preschooler fully engaged

author: Nicole
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2020
review_content: I bought this for my 5yr old in kindergarten and he LOVES to play this game! He asks to play it randomly throughout the day, and little does he know, he's learning! It's hard enough to try to teach kids their sight words over and over.. but turning learning into a fun competitive game is great!  The only thing I was say negatively is that I wish it had more sight words.. maybe the makers could come up with a zingo 2 to add more words 😁 other than that, its great!
title: Highly recommend, my 5yr old loves it!

author: Helenius Monk
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2018
review_content: This game has really helped my 5yo be enthusiastic about adding and counting. And it’s fun. I actually don’t mind playing this 8 times in a row 🤨 Can’t ask for much more.
title: Fun way to learn

author: K teach & mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2020
review_content: What a fun memorization and matching game for sight words! My friend had this at Christmas for her Kindergartener. As a teacher, sight words are so important to the success of emergent readers. I wanted to be sure I started my son practicing these words so that he can feel successful when he needs to know them. My son loves this game.
title: Fun Sight Word Practice!!!

author: Seraphin03
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2020
review_content: I wish the deaignera would have used different tiles and not have any repeats. The game is set for 4-7yr ols and has repeated tiled one must call out before other in ofder to obtain them. A four year old doesnt have the same speed and reaction as a seven year old. Therefore they are at a disasvantage to begin with. Furthermore I wish the tiles were able to be placed in any direction on their case. Makes for harder and longer setup when all tiles can only go one direction back into their slot. Otherwise its a neat game
title: Wish it were designed differently

author: MINA
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2019
review_content: The Zingo is such a fun game to play. The chips included do not fade away with regular use, we have had it for atleast 6 months and no problems. No scratches, fading of the color. The play cards it comes with are laminated and therefore they are very sturdy. If you dont throw the cards around and take care of the game, it will last you for many many years. Great buy.
title: Loads of fun

author: DakOdin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2017
review_content: My kids (3 and 5) love the original Zingo game. I decided to get the Sight Words one to mix it up a little bit. So far, it is a bit challenging for them but I can tell they are quickly learning. They do tend to want to play this one less than the original Zingo but that's okay. It's a great introduction to sight words and it makes them really concentrate on the game at hand.
title: Fun!

author: Jessica
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
review_content: If you’re considering buying this game because it looks like it could be fun for your preschool aged child, do yourself a favor and just click “buy now”! This game is so adorable and so much fun! We bought this one and also the number version. They’re both great but this one is my favorite! We finally get to play a fun game for the whole family. My little guy is 4 and absolutely loves this game! Even though he can’t read yet he loves it! It’s a great game and also very educational. This is a great game for ALL age groups!
title: This game is worth every penny!

author: Sabrina E.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2019
review_content: This is a cute game. My 6 and 4 year old really seem to enjoy it. However, I have to be the one to very gently slide it back and forward to reveal the new chips, and sometimes I even have to lift the top of it off; which is kind of a bummer because part of the fun for them is moving it themselves. I don't know if we got a lemon, but it's probably worth mentioning. I say try it for yourself. Maybe you won't have any issues!
title: Fun For Littles, But Ours Gets Jammed

author: Wren
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2019
review_content: This game is fun to play and is helpful for reinforcing sight word identification.I deducted one star because the particular game we received has a sticky sliding mechanism. When you slide the "chip" holder forward, it often sticks, slowing down play. But we have another version of Zingo that doesn't have this problem, so I suspect this issue was particular to the game we received.We've only used the sight word version of Zingo a couple of times, but I expect it to be as durable as the other version of Zingo we've had for years (the materials appear to be equally durable). Our regular Zingo game, which we've payed many times over the years, is still in excellent condition.
title: Good learning tool

author: Amanda Burrier
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2019
review_content: Loving this game! My 4.5 year old is wanting to play this pretty much every single day. It’s easy to play and even after playing is constantly it never gets old. He loves to play this more with multiple people to make it more competitive rather than just with two people. The mechanism that releases the tiles does get stuck every once in awhile. It also spits out four tiles sometimes. So it is kind of frustrating not knowing if it is going to work right. However it hasn’t stopped us from playing.
title: Great game for four year old

author: LYNZ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_content: I bought a handful of word-type games for our family to play together with my little one (4 years old) and this game is GREAT! It's very easy to understand (bingo, picture-matching) and helps to associate spelling with the pictures as well. The little mechanism to eject the tiles is really exciting for kiddos to use and the competition aspect of it is gentle and fun. My little one even sits and plays it by herself if we aren't available.
title: Best game ever for my 4 year old!

author: Dan Trachtman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2020
review_content: This game is very well constructed and thoughtfully designed. It is far better than any other Bingo type game I have seen and it alone is practically getting us through Corona days at home. Even though it says ages 4 and up, my 2yr old gets it too!My only tiny quibble is that it says the red boards are harder than the green ones.  We have played both sides extensively and you will fill either color equally fast. There is not difference.
title: Fantastic game w/one small caveat

author: J. McClintic
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2020
review_content: Got this game for a 4 year old for Christmas. She still loves to play zingo with anyone that will play it with her. It's a relatively fast paced game that keeps her attention and sometimes we play 3 rounds. There's only two small problems with the game. One is that sometimes the dispenser gets jammed up with two game pieces. The other is that sometimes the pieces don't fall back into the dispenser correctly so they end up piled in the dispenser all cattywampus.
title: Great game easy to learn

author: Veronica Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2020
review_content: The kids love the game and the concept. It made a great gift, however the Zingo slider often distributed more than the tiles it’s supposed to which messes with the flow of the game. Also replacing the unused tiles back into the slider is unnecessarily difficult. It’s as if the return slots are too small for the tiles and you have to apply more pressure than you would think.Overall the 4 and 7 year old play this game together but there are glaringly obvious improvements to be made
title: Fun for the kids.

author: E Scrima
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2019
review_content: Bought this for my 5 year old niece.  She very quickly learned how to play - Really helps with matching skills - was not only checking her card but all of ours to find matches. Sometimes the dispenser dispensed more than it should but overall this is a good purchase for the money.  Plus the games last a little while and for a 5 year old 5-7 minutes can feel like an hour.  The game really held her attention and we often played 3-5 games in a row.  Excellent buy!
title: Great way to pass the time

author: Tina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2018
review_content: Bought Zingo Bingo about 3 years ago and it was well made. Unfortunately the construction is not has good. The tiles get stuck or come out 2 at a time finally gave up. Very disappointed
title: Unfortunately the construction is not has good. The tiles get stuck or come out 2 ...

author: gg&pops
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
review_content: We had such a fantastic time playing this game! There were 5 of us between the ages of 6 & 48, and we all enjoyed this so much! We made our own rules & had teams using the different colored sides & we also played until someone filled their entire board, so it got a bit exciting towards the end of each game, because there was usually at least 2 of us waiting for the same tile to win - don't forget to yell ZINGO!
title: An awesome family game!

author: Satoshi Tsurusaki
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2019
review_content: We love the original (picture) zingo game. The word builder version however is just collecting dust. I sometime use it to make A-Z bingo using A-Z bingo cards (not included).  That is more fun. The A-Z zingo chips don't include all of the letters from the alphabet, and the letters are all caps, so it's not really even great for playing bingo.
title: The word builder version is not really fun

author: Dr Janet Gray
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2020
review_content: This is a fun educational game. My granddaughter and I enjoy playing all the time.  Recommendation add more words (option of buying expanded word pack) that aligns to the 100 high frequency words for Kinder, First Grade and Second grade
title: More fun than flashcards

author: Marlene Hall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
review_content: I bought this for my almost 4 year old grandson and he LOVED it! We loved something that as a family we could all sit down and enjoy together. Usually our grandson is running through the house...climbing onto something he shouldn’t or creating havoc with his older brother but this game held his interest for nearly two hours in the 1 use. Then, over the weekend he’d ask for someone to sit down and play the game with him! It is a TERRIFIC game!
title: The BEST game ever for young children!

author: LMT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2019
review_content: My grandsons ages 3 & 5 found Zingo easy to learn and fun to play.  “No reading necessary” feature gave them, both despite the age difference, a level playing field.  The game chips and dispenser are made of thick quality plastic.  My only complaint is the sliding of dispenser shoot is a bit finicky and there is a learning curve even for the adults on how the drag the chip dispenser without causing chips to jam.  This did not prevent game play - the boys just took the top of the dispenser off and worked with the chips showing.  Overall an enjoyable game, very appropriate for preschoolers and energing readers, with multiple educational uses for the picture chips.
title: Appealing Game For Preschoolers

author: Jules
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2019
review_content: My grandson is 4 and really enjoyed the game! We have the picture Zingo so he was familiar with the rules. We always made it part of the game to review our card out loud and see how many of ours matched! He’s an emerging reader and it will help so much with the words you just need to memorize. I especially like the picture prompts that came with words like “over” “under” “he” “ she” etc. The slide was a little stiff at first but should ease up with use.
title: Wonderful enrichment game!

author: Erica Godsey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2017
review_content: Awesome game! I bought this for my grandson who was having slight difficulty with his sight words and needed some extra help. There are so many different ways that you can play this game. You can even make up your own way to play that works for your child and keep your child's interest. My grandson absolutely loved playing. It allowed him to learn without feeling like he was doing homework... Rather it was just a fun game for him. He benefited greatly from this. His sight word recognition improved 100% And he is now reading. I can't say enough about this wonderful educational tool.
title: Best Educational tool to help young children learn their sight words...  great game kids will want to play often

author: Anniesa Jiménez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
review_content: My daughter is in 2nd grade and we with quarantine and summer vacation coming. We want the kids to stay active in learning. This is a great game! I can play with my 7yr old and my 3 year old at the same time!One side of the card is addition e.g.  picture of 2 stars + a picture of 5 cars =7 (number she wild was mark of her card) yay - side my 7 years uses.  Helps with adding and quickly!!The other side has basic number 1,2,3,4 etc side my 3 year old use to help him identify the numbers!We will be buying the other zingo games!
title: Great learning game!

author: Sydney Hughes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2020
review_content: I bought this game to use with my kindergarten students to help support them as they continue to learn their numbers and basic addition! I absolutely LOVE playing it with them, and know that they love it as well. It’s fun and engaging for them, as well as being interactive. I love that the Zingo board is double sided, so I can continue to use it with them as they advance. This game was totally worth the money, and I am SO glad that I invested in it!
title: Fun game for number learning!

author: GG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2018
review_content: My son could play this game for HOURS!  He loves the picture Zingo better because he doesn't know all of his sight words yet, but this game has definitely helped him recognize and learn more sight words.  Even when he doesn't know the word, he matches letters and letter patterns to help him try and win!! And he LOVES to win!!  I wish this game came in even more variations, it's a great concept and it keeps kids learning without even knowing!!
title: Best game ever!!

author: PJH
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2020
review_content: Super fun game that's easy to learn and very interactive. I bought this to play with my grandchildren, ages 4 1/2 and a little over 2 year old. It wasn't complicated but it's a good idea to play a game first before you try it out with a child. With a bit of modification, so the 2 year old could play, we had a lot of fun with the game. It was engaging enough that we played about 4 rounds. I would recommend it.
title: FUN!

author: Weatherfree
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2020
review_content: I ordered this for our six year old granddaughter to play when she comes to our house. She loved it. She & I played it several times during the week she visited. I am very pleased with the game. It is exactly like described. We also liked the action of how cards are dispensed. She would yell “zing” so we had a lot of fun.  This would make a nice gift for a young child ages (5-7) who likes to play games.
title: Great, easy and fun game for a young child

author: SLS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2019
review_content: The deck consistently got stuck in the machine or shot out 2 words at a time and there is no difference between the red and yellow sides of cards.
title: Too hard for pre-K, too easy for 1st grade

author: Winter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2020
review_content: I bought this for my grandson‘s fifth birthday and he and his two-year-old sister love it! They play it every day! My daughter says her five-year-old plays it reading the words and her two-year-old from the pictures. I would recommend it. My grandson sent me a thank you card and he drew a picture of them all playing zingo around the table.
title: Fun  family game

author: J. Lee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2020
review_content: Feels overpriced and overrated. Very limited words. The speedy taker getting the word panel doesn’t really work with varying age group either so we changed the rule to make it more fun. I have a bunch of other thinkster games but this one could have been skipped. Just get the regular bingo at much lower price from another company.
title: Ok

author: Sparkies
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2020
review_content: I was looking for a game to work on number sense. This game helps  with that. However, it is more oriented to older kids. My 4 and 5 year old had a blast but struggled with subitizing because there were too many objects to count. If this game came with boards with less objects (more oriented for litter ones) this works have been a success in our house.
title: Not designed for children under 6

author: Jessica Callen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
review_content: My son has an expressive speech delay, we first were introduced to this game by his speech therapist and he had so much fun with it that I decided to get it for his birthday. It's a great game for younger kids, all the fun of bingo while also helping them with word recognition and vocabulary. My son loves it and asks to play almost daily.  Well made, easy to use, simple rules with different variations of the game, and durable!
title: Great for younger kids!

author: Jon Haines
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2019
review_content: My son absolutely loves this game.  It's just bingo with words and shapes to match but the process of getting it to spit out to little cards is fun for the 2-4 year old crowd.  While the mechanism that it uses to push back and forth can be a little finicky, the game itself is a really simple and solid concept.
title: Great game for language building

author: Lance
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
review_content: My hyperactive 3-year old can't sit still for 45 seconds, but he LOVES Zingo!  Great learning tool on many levels.  Helps learn how to play games with rules and sit still for 10-20 minutes at a time, on top of the word/image learning aspects of it.  Absolute home run.  (This review is for "regular" Zingo - but we will be buying more)
title: PERFECT game for toddlers

author: The cheated on spouse
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2016
review_content: I think this game is great! My only problem is the lack of the complete alphabet in this. My son likes to build other 3 letter words from the tiles after we've completed the boards.  He was extremely disappointed that he couldn't spell the word Z-O-O because there isn't a Z. Once I looked closer there is no Q either.
title: I think this game is great! My only problem is the lack of the ...

author: Karen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2015
review_content: I got this for my 6 year old for Christmas.  We have loved it!  It is allowing him great practice on his sight words during the Christmas break.  He has had so much fun.  He generally ends up just shouting out the words on the chips whether he needs it for his card or not!  The fun has gotten my 4 year old interested.  He is already beginning to pick up on some words.  I love TV shows and games that encourage learning in such a fun way that they don't realize they are learning!  I will probably look into some of the other Zingo games for our home!
title: Too much fun!  And learning at the same time!

author: Tamara
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2020
review_content: I got this for my little one who was struggling with counting. She has since flourished and I think it's because of this game. They've also learned some of the number words. This game teaches number recognition, subitizing, sight words, and sharing. I'll be ordering different zingo games because this was such a hit.
title: Wonderful

author: MB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2019
review_content: I purchased this for my four year old child. This has been a lot of fun for both of us to play. We have played it for several hours already. Each game can be played very quickly. It was easy to set up and learn, and there are lots of variations to the game to make it more challenging. The tiles have the word printed as well as the picture of the item. This is excellent for kids learning to read.  The tile slider is fun, too!
title: Fun to Play!

author: ruffruff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2020
review_content: My Five year old granddaughters love this game! This game is simple but a lot of fun. A friend recommended this game to me and we just love it!
title: Great family game to play with young children.

author: Mary
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2020
review_content: My 4 1/2 and 2 1/2 year old grand daughters really like this game. I am disappointed in the device that ejects the picture tiles. It doesn't work well. The tiles get stuck really often and more try to come out at a time. It's really annoying. You have to tilt the device just right which small children are not going to do.
title: Fun Game except...

author: Carina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
review_content: Love the fact that it’s simple and easy to put together and play. My four year old son loves it. The only annoying thing is that it is a triangular shape so it has three sides and only two sets of stickers so a blank side appears on some tosses and no directions for what to do; therefore we just re-do when that happens.
title: Great game for kids who love tic tac toe

author: terrance
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2018
review_content: Saw our on amazon, got good ratings, so we bought it for our 4.5 year old granddaughter. She likes it. The only problem with it if you don't go a steady speed moving the thing that puts the pieces out it tries to put 3 or 4 down,  when it's made for 2.  Granddaughter wants to move it but that's when it clogs up.  Otherwise I think it's a good game for children.
title: Variation of an old game for kids

author: Mrs. B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2018
review_content: My 1st grader loves this game. The little “zinger” is fun for her to slide and the sight words match the words they have worked on at school.
title: Perfect for my 1st Grader

author: LaToya Franklin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2020
review_content: I purchased for my twin boys they just turned 4. They learned it quickly and are enjoying it. They ask to play it daily. My daughter and I enjoy playing with them. Good for mind and motor skills. Teaches turn taking, concentration, memory, picture/word recognition and sportsmanship. Great game all around.
title: Must Have Family Games for Youngsters

author: Sheila L. Stovall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2020
review_content: I ordered them for a child that had never used any “sight words cards.” She liked the cards and thought the colors were expressive. (My term, not hers.)
title: Can you see the sight words?

author: jennifer b nash
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2018
review_content: My son's preschool class had this game and he loved it so we got one for home. It is SO fun for the kids! Easy to play and store I highly recommend.  It does say ages 4 and up but my son and his friends all just turned 3 and they play it perfectly.  I have actually made this my go-to gift for fellow toddler parents because so few people know what it is but everyone loves it after they play. :)
title: A must have for toddler moms!

author: nicoleb
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2020
review_content: I had purchased Zingo with words. My 5 year old loved it. I ordered the Zingo math and am equally pleased. I plan to get a few of these for gifts. educational and fun for all ages!!
title: Great tool for teaching young ones math

author: Mallory
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2018
review_content: We love this game! Got it for a family vacation and it was the perfect first “board” game for our 3.5 year old daughter. She loves playing it and totally gets the concept/rules. The pictures and play are easy enough for a three year old to follow but the game is still interesting enough for adults to play with them. Highly recommend. Keep in mind that it does have small parts (as an FYI in case you have babies in the house).
title: Fabulous family game for three year old

author: Ania Mar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2020
review_content: 3yr old loves to play and match and pull out the tiles. This game teaches her taking turns and word and picture matching.
title: Worth the price if your child has stamina to sit and play

author: DM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020
review_content: We love playing this game with our kids, and recently ordered another to donate as a gift to our son's school.  It's like Bingo for sight words. We play it with our 4 and 7 year olds, so even if they can't read, they're still able to enjoy it. Highly recommend!
title: Fun and educational!

author: Humour
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2020
review_content: My kid loves it. Very entertaining. But SERIOUSLY it is some pieces of plastic and a few pieces of cardboard. Way over-priced. I don't even see commercials for this thing so not sure what I paid for but pretty sure plastic and cardboard are the cheapest materials on earth.
title: Great But Expensive

author: Caitlyn Anne
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2019
review_content: Like some other reviews mention, there are a lot of repeats of words and not all the words are sight words from either Fry or Dolch lists so it is kind of confusing for young learners.  But it is a great game and concept that kids love!
title: Great concept

author: Emily D
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
review_content: We were gifted this game recently and it’s perfect for little kids! My 2 year old can’t play a lot of games yet, except this one.Love it for quality family time, and all parties involved can learn something new.So when the opportunity arose to purchase a gift for our family friends with kids around our age, we knew exactly what to get them!With prime shipping, it arrived exactly when it was projected to. date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2018

They want to push down on it, which makes the tile pieces get stuck in there.  I'm still teaching him to just push it gently forward and back, so an adult is still needed to play this game.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2018

Kids this age love familiarity and repetition and it isn't too mind numbing for adults.  It helps her to learn to be a good winner and a good loser.  I highly recommend Zingo!

author: Sara
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2019
review_content: This is our favorite game right now! We play a lot of games during the cold months and this one we play daily. My 3 and 5 year old love it

author: TD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: We have had this game for several years and all my children love it! They play with their 3 year old sister and there are different levels to challenge the older kids. Not just about reading words, it’s about playing a game and teaching good lessons about winning and losing.

author: Midwest Mike
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2014
review_content: We bought this game because our daughter plays this at preschool, she brought it up over and over. We found it on amazon and got it a few weeks ago. As this is the only moving part in the game I expect it to hold up well for all of our children and future children.Great game! I recommend for any young ones learning letters and starting to learn to read.We recommend for sure!

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2020
review_content: We bought this for our 5 year old who is on the autism spectrum. He loves it! My husband and I even play a few more games after our son has moved on to something else lol.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2020
review_content: Haven’t been able to get my kindergartener motivated in the quarantine to practice studies. He’s having a blast playing this with his fourth grade sister. The mechanism for spitting out the words definitely keeps them engaged! Love it

author: justin younes
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2017
review_content: My 4 year old loves the original Zango. We have been working on reading and she had a lot of trouble with sight words so we got this for her for Christmas.  I was hesitant. author: Shop Lady
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2020
review_content: My grandkids love playing this game because they get to slide the box to reveal which two letter they will get. The bingo aspect of the game is new to them and they are having fun playing it. I like that they are learning while playing.

author: Nic Nymh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2020
review_content: This game is a great teaching tool and has a little more variability than traditional bingo. My (recently turned) 5yo LOVES it, and my 10 yo has been able to brush up on addition skills while playing with us while not feeling bored!Definitely a great addition to your game shelf, and a good gift!

author: Nigel S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2020
review_content: My son is autistic and likes to play various puzzles to learn vocabulary. The price of these puzzles is reasonable and the quantity is pretty large. I bought a lot of combinations to take him to study to increase his willingness to learn.
title: my son likes it

author: Crystal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2015
review_content: It's a fun way to sneak in some math skills for your kids. Here's a breakdown of basic game play:You have a card, like a bingo card, with nine squares that you need to cover to win. One side just has squares with a number of objects and the number word (e.g. eight cars and the word "eight"). The other side has an addition problem with just pictures (e.g. five hearts, a plus sign, and two more hearts)At each turn, two tiles come out the the dispenser.Players can take one or both tiles if the number on the tile matches a number or solution on their card, and places the tile on the correct square.There are no real turns, each player can grab one or both tiles at every dispersion, so you have to think fastAny unneeded tile goes back in the dispenserThe first player to cover all nine tiles wins.My kids like to play (6 and 10 years old) and we have fun.
title: Fun game with a little thinking about early math

author: Kerjay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2020
review_content: My kids absolutely love this game. Perfect for them!!! Play many many many games! Ages 3 and 5

author: Tre-J
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2014
review_content: My daughter is in Kindergarten and we enjoy playing this game together. This is our third Zingo style game so familiar with the actions of playing. She has had half the words in school and this game exposes her to new ones. i would have liked to see a larger number of words.... there are multiple tiles of same words but the variety of words is lacking. I accidentally ordered two of this product (darn buy with 1 click!) I decided to donate one to her K classroom and they now use it a few times a week during centers. on a side note the donated game had a Zinger that didn't slide well and tiles got stuck on first day out of box. I contacted THINKFUN and they replaced immediately. Thinkfun has great customer service!

author: bellasmama

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2019

author: SFBeav
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2019
review_content: Heard about this game from another mom and decided to snag one to play during the holidays and it was a HIT! My son loves playing it and it’s fun for the adults too. It’s a perfect game for kids in different age groups because of the icon-matching system. Highly recommend.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
review_content: Bought this for my 5 year old son and he loves it! He likes it, I like it and his step sister love playing with him too so all in all it was a good find. Would definitely recommend!

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2019

author: Jose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2020
review_content: My two year old absolutely loves this game. It’s easy to use and it’s helping her with spelling; as we spell out each word on the chips when placing it on our game boards.

author: Yoko Tachibana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2018
review_content: We use this zingo game for learning English in Japan. Students love to play it .Becuase they are excited to find  the next cards come out from the Zingo machine . A student ask the other students '' Do you have a bat ? '' And the others answer '' Yes, I have a bat '' or '' No, I don't have a bat "  . The one says '' It's your turn " '' It's my turn '' . They try to speak English as much as possible . We use the other zingo games ,too .
title: This is the second one

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2020
review_content: Awesome game! My 3 year old loves it and we can play it with her. It’s taught her how to play a game, be competitive and improve her matching skills. We love it so much we give it for birthday gifts now. Highly recommend.

author: Lindsey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2020
review_content: I gifted this to my 4 yo toddler and he has loved playing it.  It was easy for him to grasp and follow and maintained his attention for the entire game.  I recommend!
title: Great toddler game

author: jenn7142
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2014
review_content: My daughter really enjoys this game.  When she first opened it, she mostly just wanted to play with the tiles and feed them back into the 'Zinger'.  I had to watch though, because she would try to shove them in backwards and then it would get stuck.  It's pretty easy to fix, though.  The tiles and Zinger are made of sturdy plastic and should last well beyond when our infant is old enough to read. The player cards are similar in weight to the pages of a child's board book and have a shiny coating.  The length of the game is just long enough for a preschooler's attention span.  I like that the game includes words like the, three, and there; and went, what, and want - she has to really pay attention to the differences in the letters and not just guess at the words.
title: Fun for my 4-year-old

author: CVM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2018
review_content: This was a gift to our son when he turned 4. It is excellent to help in learning sight words and to play by himself and with others. We now use it for our toddler when we play together or she plays with older brother. We've since bought it as a gift for others.
title: Fun game to learn sight words

author: Carla B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2020
review_content: No little breakable pieces. Very sturdy. Super fun to play with my 5 & 7 year old kids. They love it! I like that the 2 sides have different ways to play

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2019
review_content: I bought this as a game for grandma's house for our 4.5 and 2.5 year old grandkids.  And it's a hit, even for the 2.5 year old who only looks at the pictures for now.  It's good for both of them to remember to take turns when they want the same game piece.  The only comment I have is you have to take some care with sliding the bingo game pieces out of their holder (can't be rough as you'll get more than two pieces at a time and they'll get stuck.)  This is a great game.
title: Great fun!

author: Deborah Lynn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2017
review_content: I bought Zingo as a gift for my four year old granddaughter and we have played it "umpteen" times already!  She loves it! She even enjoys playing with the little picture chips in imaginative ways as well.  This is a great game to gradually introduce young children to the idea of playing a game that involves taking turns and some simple rules.  My granddaughter likes to play where one only wins by filling the entire board because it makes the game last longer.  I highly recommend this game.  I know she will enjoy it for a long time!  (Zingo also makes another version that uses simple words instead of pictures that can help children with reading.  I bought that one too!)

review_content: We have another Zingo game (the one with the pictures only) and my son loved it. author: L. Allison
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2012
review_content: I gave this gift to my 5 year old grandson.  He had been given weekly "sight words" in Kindergarten and has learned all of them proudly.  When I saw this game I realized it would fit right into his learning routine.  He loves it.  The idea that he has to recognize and pronounce the new word and then match it on his "zingo" card makes learning new words very exciting for him.  As he comes across a new word he works at sounding it out (a little help at times).  He has "sight learned" several new words already.  This game is good for a child at least 5 years of age who has had some Pre-K or K education, or has been already taught to sound out written words.
title: Sight Words fun and educational

I would say it's good for 4-7 year olds after that it might not be a challenge.

author: pirate&princessmommy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2016
review_content: We received this game in the mail yesterday and could not stop playing it.  Although challenging for my almost 3 year old, he still enjoyed the process.  My almost 5 year old loved it.  I have no doubt this game will help my children learn to love words.  I was a tad bit skeptical before I ordered this game but, upon receiving it, I can't wait to try out another.  The tiles are plastic, not cardboard as I anticipated.  The playing cards have two sides.  The yellow side is for beginners and each word only has one letter missing.  Multiple letters will fit to make a word.  As we played, we spelled each word.  For example, one of the words was ___ AT.  Several consonants would fit into that blank to make a word.  This game opens up many opportunities to talk about site words, word families, rhyming words etc.  I know this will be a family favorite for many years to come.Both the cards and the tiles are heavy duty.  The playing "zinger" is made of hard plastic.  Both my almost 3 year old and my almost 5 year old loved moving the zinger to reveal the letters.  My almost 3 year old was calling out the letters as they appeared.
title: Awesome Educational Game!

author: RuthM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020

author: Moore-Al
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2016
review_content: Zingo games are great fun for kids and their parents! In the first Zingo, it's a bingo game with picture tiles that eject from a dispenser (controlling the dispenser is part of the appeal), then its Zingo with sight words (big incentive to learn to read them) — with cards cleverly designed with mnemonic devices to assist memory by association — then it's on to Zingo with numbers, and clock faces..... who knows what's next? It looks like the game we all grew up with, in the capable hands of Zingo's developers ThinkFun, can be used to learn to match, to read, to identify numbers, and to tell time! I can't wait to see what they come up with next. I highly recommend both Zingo and all ThinkFun games.
title: I Love Zingo

author: Chris Levine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2012
review_content: I really wanted to love this game. It gets great reviews and is educational. My 5 year old finds it too easy, so I don't feel he is learning at all with it. There is only addition and I should have known this but its not 5 + 7, its really 5 items + 7 items which means he just quickly counts them all and doesn't have to think much. It may just be me and the level that my 5 year old is in math. I wish it was more chalanging for him. I was completely board as there really is no catch its just bingo. I love other thinkfun games and I love educational games in general. I just don't particularly like this one. There also should be more cards and they could be of better quality. Sadly the 3 year old really didn't like it much either :-(
title: Wanted To Love It, Not Much Fun Sadly, Too Easy 5 Year Old, Boring For Adults

author: Bethany17
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2011
review_content: I bought this game since we love the original Zingo! game.  We just opened it the other day and the kids love it!  My kids are 7 and 5 and both can play this game.  The green side of the card is better for my younger son since it has pictures.  For example, the card might have one star or two shells, etc. up to twelve.  The red side is more challenging and perfect for my 7 year-old.  That side has things like 1 star + 2 stars and then she would put a "3" game piece on it.  It gets her thinking a bit while freshening up on simple addition facts.Zingo! games are awesome and highly, highly recommended.  They are some of the best and most fun educational games out there!
title: Another awesome Zingo! game!
