author: ShanaDee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2010
review_content: I have the original Zingo! game in my Preschool classroom and my students LOVE it!! When I heard of Zingo 1-2-3 and found it @ Amazon (at least [...] cheaper than the teacher catalogs that come to my school), I immediately jumped on it.  The game teaches number recognition, grouping, counting, and even operations. Zingo 1-2-3 is very age and developmentally appropriate and children are learning while playing - doing addition and not even realizing it!  I have parents who went out and purchased the game for home and came back talking of how the whole family played the game and had so much fun!!  Its a face paced, loud game as everyone is racing to be the quickest to fill their card and shout ZINGO!
title: Fun and Educational Toy

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2012
review_content: Like the original zingo game, be careful when pulling it down to play.  My children never want to stop playing it.  Zingo 1-2-3 introduces some basic math, which can get frustrating as an adult as your child counts the items on the card over and over again and you slide new numbers.  The younger the player, the harder it is for them to remember what number they need on the card.  I would not recommend it for children under 5 unless you are very patient.  I'm not sure if it really helps with the math, but it does help with counting and be ready count A LOT with a younger child.  I prefer the original zingo game probably because I am not patient.  All the zingo games are great and have been played over and over again in our house.
title: Zingo crack

author: Careful Consumer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2013
review_content: This is a great educational tool. I worked as a reading specialist this summer and my students begged to play it. The slider really makes the game exciting!  I saw improvements in how they read sight words in isolation in just two weeks. They started to pay more attention to the letters in the words.I used with struggling readers entering third grade who found it challenging because of they read below grade level. It would probably be best used with first and seconds graders or third graders with reading difficulties.I would just be careful about using it with younger children.  I have hesitated and not given it to my niece who is in kindergarten but I will this summer before she enters first grade, if and only if I feel she is ready.  There are other versions of Zingo which are great for pre-schoolers. She has one and loves it.
title: Awesome Game

author: Talia Torres
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2015
review_content: Very fun game. A bit fast paced if you forget to slow down for the little ones (our mistake). My 4 year old cousin had a little trouble keeping up with the rules of the game, but she did enjoy this game. The tiles are big & easy to grip, but they are a bit strange to pop back into the little container during play. The tile holder has two very slim openings for you to pop them in & they tend to get stuck in the process. You quickly realize that maybe you've been trying to pop the tile back in the wrong way, but that isn't the case. Otherwise fun for the entire family, but don't forget to pretend that you can't count well either! ;]

author: Kidney4Canyon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2016
review_content: This is such a high quality and fun game.  I bought this for my grade K daughter to try and get ahead in class.  The cute little machine is made from thick plastic and is very easy to use.  Simply lift the top off of it, load the little sight word cards (also made from thick plastic),put the cover back on, and push down on the top of it.  This pushes the cards onto the bottom of the tray.  The play cards are thick and very easy to read.  All in all, it's been a huge hit with her - even my older kids!  Tons of fun and well worth the money.

author: Lee-Loo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2018
review_content: This is a great game for kids; from those who are just learning to talk, all the way up to those who are learning to read. We started playing this game as soon as my daughter started talking & it helped her learn some of her ‘first’ words. She is now almost 3 & we work on recognizing the beginning letter as we draw each tile. I have no doubt & high hopes that as the years go by she will begin to recognize the words as ‘sight words’!Another great plus to this game is that it can be played with just her & I or she can play with friends! Even her 10yr old brother enjoys playing this with her.The quality of this game is excellent as well! The boards are thick cardboard that hold up well to little fingers & the tile slider ‘thingy’ is nice & smooth & we never have any issues with it (unless it gets loaded improperly). Even the box is a nice thick cardboard for easy, long lasting  storage. I love that I didn’t have to buy a container for it, as organization & easy clean up are huge in our house! (Sometimes it’s the little things that make a product that much better!)Overall it is an excellent quality, fast paced, fun game that keeps their attention & teaches them new words, letter recognition & sight words that can be played for many years! We plan on buying the other Zingo games too!
title: Awesome game to play with kids as soon as they are able to start talking!

author: Christine1e
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
review_content: Disclosure: I purchased this item at a promotional price in exchange for sharing my honest feedback. In order to be fair I've reviewed it with the actual price in mind. I depend heavily on reviews when I make purchases online and try to write useful reviews. If find this review helpful, I would appreciate you marking it helpful. Thanks!This is so fun! My kids are 2, 4, and 6, so there are not a ton of board games we can all play together. Zingo combines words and pictures on small plastic tiles. This allows both boys to participate--the pictures are very clear and are good representations of the objects. The words are common ones and easy to read.It is very well designed. The team has definitely thought of the important aspects of a game for ages 4+. The tiles are durable and the mechanism to choose tiles is simple. Less pieces to break! The game includes 78 tiles, which are stored in the dispenser plus 7 double sided cards. To make it more challenging as your kids grow and become quicker at reading and recognizing the words on the cards, you switch from the green side to the red side. The red cards share more words, so there is more competition for the tiles.I am delighted to find a game that is compact to store, durable, interesting for a variety of ages, adaptable, and not based on cartoon characters. I am so glad that I can enjoy playing it too. It isn't complicated but it still holds their attention.The mechanism to deliver the tiles is actually simple and slides smoothly enough that my 2 year old was able to use it. It kept her from stealing the tiles off the cards, too!It's a good value and the designers were thoughtful in their planning. We're going to try it out with the 9 and 13 year old cousins tomorrow and I'll update.
title: I depend heavily on reviews when I make purchases online and try to write useful reviews. If find this review helpful

author: Comtesse Gigi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2018
review_content: If you have a child like mine, taking turns is a challenge, the idea of losing is mind melting, and patience is not yet a virtue.  Zingo is a great game to start using those skills at an early age.  While this game is mostly touted for teaching pre-reading skills, I have found that it is a great game for learning to take turns.  Learning to lose graciously is so not easy so this game is a great starter to ease into that.  I've found that the sting of losing hurts a little less when you allow everyone to cover their board, but also state, "this person actually won the game since they covered the board first, but everyone finished."In Zingo there are yellow chips with various pictures, smile, shoe, cat, dog with the word written on the bottom.  There are 6 "bingo" cards with those various pictures on them as well.  One person slides the red chip holder forward and two chips slide out.  If you have one of those pictures on your board, shout out the word first and you get the chip to cover your board.  The first person to cover every picture wins the game.  The two sides are merely easy and more competitive.  You can choose to do regular bingo rules like four corners or X marks the spot.  Cleanup is easy because the chips all sit in the red holder.  Kids love the game because of the red slider and ability to use their outside voice inside, and adults love it because surprise!, you're learning!
title: Great Game for learning Pre-Game Skills

author: Alison
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2014
review_content: My 4 year old daughter absolutely loves this game! As a mom, I love that she is asking me to play an educational game rather than to watch tv or use electronics. It is great for helping to build early reading and spelling skills. My daughter had a lot of fun sliding the "zinger" back and forth to reveal the letters. There are both beginner and advanced levels so no matter what your child's skills are they will still enjoy it. It starts with simple 3 letter words where you only need 1 letter to make a complete word and then advances to adding multiple letters to create a word. Definitely a fun game for the kids - the will not only like to play, but they will learn while doing it!I received a Zingo! Word Builder game free from ThinkFun to review
title: Educational AND the Kids Actually Like to Play It!

But then they also like millions other toys that are more educational and more fun to me as a parents.

author: V. Dean
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2014
review_content: I am a school-based speech-language pathologist working with K-5th grade and received this game as a free donation to my Speech room from ThinkFun in exchange for an honest review. If you have played the regular version of Zingo!, you will have a good idea of how this game works. Zingo! Word-Builder is similar to the original in that the game consists of game boards, plastic tiles, and a "Zing Zinger" (tile machine).The game boards feature 3-letter words, with one or two of the letters missing. On their turn, players move the Zing Zinger to release two tiles and have to figure out if the letters can be used to create words on their game board. The person to complete their board first is the winner. There are two difficulty levels: one side of the board is missing only one letter (in either initial, medial, or final position), and the other side is missing 1-2 of the letters. One thing that is great about the game boards and plastic tiles is that all vowels are highlighted in red. This makes it very visual for beginning readers. Another positive aspect about this game is that the Zing Zinger now has slots on the top so that you can discard your tiles more easily (unlike my other/older version).I played this game with my Speech students (Kindergarten through 2nd grade) and we had a lot of fun! This activity was great for practicing basic decoding skills and trying to figure out whether the created word was a real word or a non-sense word (only real words are allowed). Here are some additional ways you could adapt this game for Speech or reading practice -- many of them targeting phonological awareness skills:*have players identify the beginning/middle/ending sounds*have players try to come up with rhyming words*prior to letting players move the Zing Zinger, ask them about the possible words they could make and which letters they would need*when players create a word, have them make a sentence using the word*after players make a word, ask them what other words they could have made if they had had the letter ___ instead*have players substitute sounds, e.g., "You made the word 'bat'. What word do we get if we say /h/ instead of /b/?"All in all, this is a great game that builds early reading skills. Highly recommended!
title: Educational game to build basic reading skills

author: Lynn81
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2014
review_content: My family loves games. Every weekend we get together and have game night. This past weekend we played Zingo Word Builder, its a fun game and it helps kids learn to spell. Its a lot like Bingo. It comes with 1 Zingo Zinger, 72 Letter Tiles, 6 Double-sided Zingo Cards and Instruction and a Learning Guide. It is a 2-6 player game. The double-sided card is yellow on one side for beginners and the other side is orange for advanced which was great because the younger kids used the yellow side while the older kids used orange and the adults used 2 cards to level the playing field. First you choose a dealer, the dealer slides the zinger forward and back revealing letter tiles players look at their card and try to be the first one to yell out a 3 letter word using either of the tiles whoever calls it out first takes the tile and places it on their card to form the word they called out.  The other tile can be claimed the same way any unclaimed tile goes back into the zinger. The first player to fill their card (or cards) and calls out Zingo! wins. I highly recommend this game it is fun for the whole family and the kids learn while they play. I got this game free from ThinkFun to review and I am so happy that I did!
title: So Much Fun!!! The Kids Won't Even Know They Are Learning.

author: Doug Fenichel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2020
review_content: I purchased a second game for my granddaughter in Florida. We are having difficulty with too many tiles dispensing at once. We get 4 or 6 tiles at a time. We have the same game at our house and it works fine, only 2 tiles come out like it’s suppose to. This is very frustrating for our 3 year old granddaughter.  Can this be fixed? We purchased for a gift and recently opened it. It is after the return period.We love to play the game with each granddaughter, one is 5, who lives in Connecticut And the other on Florida. Good for learning sight vocabulary words and encourages reading skills and letter sounds.
title: Good for 3-6 year olds

author: Bluerose's Heart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2016
review_content: My boys are 3, 5, and 7(almost 8), and they all enjoy this game. As a bonus, it requires NO batteries!Both the game boards and the game pieces have both pictures and words on them. Your child doesn't have to be able to read to play the game, but it does make the picture/word connection, to an extent. The game goes so fast that even I tend to mostly just look at the picture, and ignore the words. There is still a slight connection, though, and every little bit helps when a little one is learning words.The game comes with 7 game boards. These are double sided. The green side is for a less competitive game, and better for the littlest ones. There aren't that many shared pictures on this side, and the players aren't in so much of a rush to grab the tiles. The red side has a bit more competition, since there are more pictures in common. The players have to rush to grab a matching tile, before someone else grabs it.Each game goes really quick, so you're not spending a ton of time on each game. There are a few different options for playing the game. You can go the traditional "Bingo" route, or you can match designs, play multiple cards, or even fill up the whole card, which is what my oldest prefers. The traditional route is just way too quick for my children's tastes.Their favorite part of the game is the Zinger. It's super easy to load the tiles, and then slide them into view. They have to take turns sliding the tiles into view, because it's so much fun. The only negative we've seen is the fact that sometimes it seems the same tile is being played over and over(in a row). When you first open the box, you'll have to mix these tiles up, since they are placed together matched. If you don't mix them up, you WILL have the same tile continue to show up in a row. Even then, it sometimes happens that the same one will keep showing up. It is easy to dump them out, mix them up, and then reload them, though.This is a super simple game, but so much fun for little ones! I even enjoy playing it with them, which is pretty important.
title: Super simple, but fun!
verified: Style: ZingoVine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )

author: Heather
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2014
review_content: I love games that help my child learn without her being aware of it. Or at least only partially aware. That’s also one of the reasons I love couponing. She’s learning math without even being conscious of it. So anything that helps her learn, while being a fun game, is a bonus. For that reason I love Zingo! Word Builder!You start off with a card with words with missing letters. The beginner side of the card is missing one letter in each word. The intermediate side of the card is missing two letters per word. You get Tiles from the tile gadget and try to place them to form actual words. You can play in just about any way you would like. Cooperatively where everyone looks at all the cards and tries to place words. In Teams. Every person for themselves. You can also mix and match the beginner cards and the intermediate cards. The possibilities are endless. Well, maybe not endless since that would be a bit of a stretch to say there are an infinite number of combinations of ways to play this game, since after all I’m sure there is some mathematical limit to the number of combinations. Wait. Where was I? Oh yeah, Ways to play Zingo! Word Builder. Want a little extra challenge? Try using a timer. It’s a little early to try the timer with my daughter; we’re just working on forming words. Watching my four year old form some words is actually pretty funny sometimes.  CJW? PKT? LAF? Obviously we’re still working on it.Disclosure: I was provided with a free copy of the game in exchange for an honest review. Regardless, all opinions expressed are 100% my own.
title: Learning games can be fun ... this one is!

author: Liz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2018
review_content: Received as a gift and this game is so much fun!! We have the regular zingo My husband and I play with my 4 yr old son ... And it is so much fun !!!Sometimes when you slide the red thing to show the cards it puts out 4 instead of 2... So just try not to press down while sliding . I can't wait to get the sight words one next year when he is in kindergarten! I highly recommend!
title: Best game !!

author: Tessa Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2014
review_content: I love this game! It is really helping my 3 year old learn to spell simple words! She has a blast trying to fit the letters in the blanks to spell things. It is one of her favorite games and she is always asking for me to pull it out. The pieces themselves are durable and well made. I love that there are two levels of board so older kids can play along with the younger ones! ThinkFun in general is an amazing company. We have several of their games and play them all the time. They are great for teaching children while they are having fun! I received this game in exchange for my honest review. All opinions expressed are 1005 my own.
title: Another great game by ThinkFun!

author: KCL
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
review_content: We LOVE this game! My kids started playing it just under 4 and 6 and they were obsessed. They still love this game at 6 and 8. And I even love to play it with them. It’s easy and fun for the whole family.I noticed some of the reviews reference words or numbers. The game may have changed over the years? The version we have is like what is shown in the pictures. There are picture tiles with the object name on them. You yell out the object if you have it on your board and get to lay the tile on your bingo (zingo) board. First to fill their board wins!
title: Best game for young kids!

author: Danielle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2020
review_content: We received Zingo Bingo with a Zing and the kids (ages 3 and 5) absolutely love this game!! We have had the game for about 3 months now and we play it several times a week. My husband and I also enjoy playing with the kids. It’s a fun interactive game and it was easy to pickup for our now 3 year old as well. Highly recommend it!! Have fun!
title: The kids love Zingo bingo!!

author: Misty Battle/Lunceford
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2014
review_content: Disclosure: I got this product as part of an advertorial.Our family loves games. Every weekend we have an evening set aside just to play games. It is a fun, family experience that allows us to unwind and relax as a family. The only thing better than game night, is adding a new game in the mix.I am really big on word games. Both my kids and I love to read, so expanding our vocabulary is something we strive to do daily. Playing educational games makes that easier to do and so much fun. ThinkFun's Zingo! Word Builder is creative, fun way to expand your child's mind. I love the easy tile holder. It makes everything cleaner and easy to store.  You slide the tile holder forward and 2 tiles are usable for the opponents.My twins had fun creating words and who could fill their card up the fastest. It was so cute to watch them race each other. I was impressed with how many words they could spell in a short amount of time. The combinations were endless. This game is a great learning tool. Definitely worth buying and using with your youngsters. My older children jumped in and was teaching them new words with the tiles. Zingo!Word Burst is a great game. This is so worth the money if you have a younger child, for a fun learning experience to build vocabulary.
title: New Game For Our Game Night

author: Jenifer S. Larson-hall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2019
review_content: I bought the Zingo sight words game for my beginning reader and he loved it. He is dyslexic and still struggling to read, so I thought the word builder game might help. The three-letter idea seemed to constrain the possibilities while still being challenging. My son didn't like it as much as the sight word game. He liked how we competed to slap our hands to get the right tile on the sight words game, and didn't like just saying a word for this game. I am also concerned because he has a lot of problems with vowels and this game, by nature of only having 3 letters, limits vowels to short vowel sounds only. That makes it too easy for his level, but might make it desirable for someone with younger children.
title: Not challenging enough for any but the most beginning reader

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2020
review_content: Our preschooler enjoys this game, but we have an issue with one of the main images being a ghost! The instructions say these images are of “familiar items” for children - sorry, but I wasn’t aware that a ghost was a familiar thing for kids!! They need to remove that tile and replace it with something that doesn’t require a discussion with a preschooler about dark spiritual beings!!
title: Get rid of the ghost tile!

author: Heidi G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: I don't know what sort of addictive substance the creators put into this game, but my toddler and all her friends are hooked.My 2.5 year old just learned this game, which she picked up in about 30 seconds. We have been bringing it along on play dates ever since then, but I should almost stop because it becomes such a favorite that kids cry when I take it home.Easy to learn, easy to play, and probably contains some sort of illegal ingredient that makes children want to play it all day.Plus as a parent concerned about child development and such, I appreciate that it not only helps my pre-literate child to use words, but also helps her develop a sense of turn-taking, concentration, and rule following.
title: Better than donuts

author: Robbie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2019
review_content: We really enjoyed this game and method of word acquisition. My K can read some but I am helping him work with fluency and speed. Learning sight words in a snap helps. He enjoys the game but the contents are  slight. More words should be included and an expansion pack should be available for more complex words.
title: needs more words and an expansion pack

author: Aliza
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2016
review_content: Bingo with a zing! Kids can easily slide the dispenser to reveal the pieces.  Players scramble to fill their boards first, with an option for a simpler level vs. a more competitive level on either side of the game card.  The pictures are recognizable to kids of all ages, and my three year old does really well with this game.  I've seen the other zingo versions, which are cool for older kids, but this is a perfect starter game for kids and I highly recommend!
title: Great starter game for kids!

author: G. Hearn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2016
review_content: Zingo-Bingo is just like bingo.  .. but with pictures/words.  Great vocabulary builder.  Though it shows for ages 4 and up, it might also work for some slightly younger kids, as they can simply look at the pictures.  I think it’s nice to have an adult/parent play along, because then they can stress the reading / spelling of each word.  Otherwise most kids are just going to look at the pictures.  Though you can play with just two players, I think it’s a little more fun with three or more.  There are a few more versions of this game, including one with numbers, and one with words.  They are all great fun and very educational.
title: Great Educational Game
verified: Style: ZingoVine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )

author: Priya
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2020
review_content: My 4 year old daughter simply loved it! This game kept her engaged for good whole 1 month, she even made her toys sit and play with her! Overall good game for pre-k. We face the problem of tiles getting stuck in the bottom of red box, but can ignore it as it’s an amazing educational game
title: Amazing game

author: OT Mommy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2012
review_content: I really love Think Fun's games.  Many I have purchased, and some I have been blessed to get for the gratis so that I can share my ever so humble opinion.  This was one of them.  Gee, twist my arm!I was super dooper excited to hear that Zingo now has a Sight Word version.  I had been trying to figure out what other concepts we could finagle out of the Zingo world.  In our game arsenal we've got the traditional, the numbers (1, 2, 3) , and the travel versions of Zingo.  There are Spanish and Hebrew versions as well, but we haven't gone that route.  I bring them to and from school on a daily basis.When Sight Word Zingo came in the mail, Mudge was eager to get our first game going.  Though the boards themselves are a little visually busy, the concept is the same.  Match the word tiles to its board counterpart.  It still has the trademark Zinger, the Zingo slider with slots for the popping in unused tiles (great for fine motor development and wrist rotation).  The 72 tiles themselves are double-sided with 24 frequently used words from the Dolch list.As Mudge is only in preschool, he did not know the words but could match the tiles by the letters.  He loved trying to figure it out.  His persistence and memory began to pay off towards the end as he recognized the groups of letters like  and, we and me.  This has proven to be a great starter game to get new readers recognizing letter combinations as words.  It is also a great review game for up to first and second graders.  Many of the children I know have requested me to bring it in for bus arrival time or indoor recess.  For children with special needs, one of my teachers even thought of using it towards her Alternate Assessments, as many of them need to identify sight words.When our game was done, I asked Mudge his favorite part to which he answered, "I like the matching Mommy."  Was there anything you didn't like?  "Well, Mommy, the red side was very difficult".  Did you not like it?  "Oh no.  I liked it, it was just difficult."Finding the just right challenge can be difficult sometimes.  But Think Fun has found another winner again for the early learners.  Sight Words Zingo is another great addition to the home and school family.  For around $20, Zingo Sight Words will happily engage young readers while helping them learn.
title: Great for the early reader arsenal!

author: Jaehee L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2019
review_content: We use it every night. Daughter is in a dual language household. She loves playing this everynight. Seems like it is missing pieces because one time we came out as a draw and no winner because there were no more shapes..... weird..
title: Hmmm..

author: AGS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2020
review_content: I gifted this game to my niece and nephew (6 and 4, respectively) for Christmas. They LOVE it! My brother tells me they don't want to stop playing it. My daughter had it when she was 4, and I swear, it was one of the tools that helped her learn to read. I highly recommend this game!
title: Great Game

author: Sherry Y. Artemenko
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2012
review_content: ThinkFun has again lived up to its name, creating a game to make learning sight words fun! Essential to learning to read, sight words are the most frequently used words in the English language. Unlike other words, they often can't be sounded out phonetically and have to be learned through visual memory, which can be frustrating to kids.  Just bring out the captivating Zinger device that reveals two word tiles per turn as players race to cover their Bingo-like Zingo card first. Some of the word spaces on the cards have graphics corresponding to the word--an "x" marks the spot for "here," a downward arrow points "in," a speech bubble surrounds "said," or a little figure waves for "me." Most of the squares have colorful patterns of stripes, checks and shapes to pair with the sight words, adding some pizazz to these critical words for reading. My little testers loved the game and wanted to play multiple rounds calling out words, "I found a 'me'," and even read the words as they reloaded the Zinger, "Can I put 'said' in the bottom?" Zingo! Sight Words engages Pre-K to 1st graders in such a fast paced game that they want to keep playing, becoming more proficient readers with each round. I love when kids are having such fun they have no idea how much they are learning!
title: Essential Learning Made Fun!

author: Lindsay Chung
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2012
review_content: Setting up the game is so easy. You simply place the word tiles inside the dispenser, pick you cards and you're good to go! One of the kids pulls the dispenser to "draw" two tiles and, if they recognize the words on the tiles as matching one of the words on their card, they take the tile and place it on their card. The remaining tile is inserted back into the dispenser through a slot in the top. The first person to fill their Zingo card wins. It's seriously easy for kids to understand and play on their own!Even my four-year-old has enjoyed playing Zingo and has learned to recognize several new words! As for my Kindergartener, several of the words are the same as the ones on her sight words lists for school, so this game is directly benefiting her school work!I was provided a copy of this game by the manufacturer in order to facilitate my honest review.
title: Great for beginning readers

author: Maggie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2019
review_content: My almost 4 year old son got this for Christmas and he loves it! I don't mind playing it with him either. The only reason I give it 4 stars is that the dispenser we have gets stuck a lot, trying to dispense 4 tiles instead of 2, so it's frustrating for my son because he can't get it unstuck himself.
title: Great game, our dispenser lacking

author: Living Chic Mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2014
review_content: Zingo! Word Builder is an awesome game perfect for kids ages 5 and up! My youngest daughter just graduated Kindergarten so I was really excited to get her this game to play and keep her vocabulary and spelling up to par over the 2 month summer break!This game is so much fun! Maiya begs to play it everyday and thankfully my older two kids (8 and 10 years old) both also enjoy the game and love helping their younger sister learn!Zingo! Word Builder helps boost confidence in early readers, guiding them to form three letter words! Playing Zingo! is very easy each player  simply slides the Zinger to reveal letters and place matches on their cards to build simple words like dog, cat and lid. As your child gets more confident in their spelling abilities you can easily increase the difficulty of the game to challenge them!
title: Fun and Educational

author: Jane Doe
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
review_content: We gave this as a gift to our nearly 4 year old granddaughter for Christmas. She LOVED it from the start. She & her parents live out of town and stayed for a week.. We played this game multiple times every day!  I am glad we bought it for her.  (I don’t write many reviews, but thought this was worth making the effort!)
title: Immediately loved- great purchase!

author: C&E
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2020
review_content: This is an awesome game for the family. My son is 3.5 and he enjoyed playing with grandparents and us together. This is really lots of fun but also teach kids words at the same time. Highly recommend it!
title: Awesome game for the family and toddler

author: LaVonne Long
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2012
review_content: I am currently homeschooling my 4 year old. We are doing Pre-K right now and learning sight words. This game is a perfect addition to schooling and the big plus? My 4 year old LOVES it. You simply load up the Zingo! Sight Words container with all the sight words, not difficult but a bit time consuming. We asked our Princess a few times to be careful no to spill the words out.Zingo! Sight Words is played like the traditional Bingo game, you match the words to the words on your card. Of course, we say all the words that are drawn out loud and have our Princess repeat the words. In this way we can reinforce the way the word looks and sounds in her mind. I feel that if we play this game enough with her she will be learning her sight words even more quickly than just during school time.If you have a child in Pre-K through 1st grade then this game is for your family!*Disclosure: I received this game for review purposes but all opinions are mine.
title: Perfect For Homeschool

author: Sunny side
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2016
review_content: My kindergartener is having so much fun with this.  After a while though you get used to the cards and the words are more a repitition.  If there were add in card packs that would be great but I notice my son isn't as enthusiastic as when we first got it.
title: Great for kindergarten kids

author: Cil King
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2020
review_content: Fun to play with our 5 year old granddaughter.  Easy to play.  Helps with picture/word recognition
title: Age appropriate..

author: Momma's Bacon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2012
review_content: I have been seeing quite a bit of sliding words games for children to help them read and acquire language and I have to say I really like that.  From what I have read, tools like Zingo have been a great addition to a children's comprehension in reading and apprehension of sight words and Brooke seems to have such fun with the sliding doors.  Zingo is a classic Bingo-style game where kids have the chance to learn up to 75 sight words while playing a brilliant and fun card game to give their reading ability a positive boost.  While you can play with another child (or up to six) or an adult, Zingo is also a game you can play independently which I really love, too.  Sight words can be a source of frustration for new readers who are not able to sound out the words and the Zingo! Sight Words game does a great job in word recognition and making the process of learning sight words fun.  I can also see where reluctant readers have the option to practice and learn on their own and can move up to a group setting at a later time.  The Zingo! Sight Words game includes 72 Zingo! sight words tiles, six double-sided Zingo! cards, Zingo! Zinger card dispenser, instructions, and a learning guide.  One awesome thing about the Zingo! game is that it offers visual cues to help the player recognize words.  Visual memory is often the key to learning sight words for children which is usually where that source of frustration comes in among early readers.  Learning sight words is considered one of the keys of language fluency and I think the Zingo! word game does an excellent job of exposing and unlocking the secret of the English language to new and emergent readers.  Well done, Think Fun!
title: Product Review:  Zingo! Sight Words Game (Age PreK+)

author: Nicole
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2016
review_content: We were gifted this game last Christmas by a friend who said she loved playing this with her son. We recently opened the box (our son is shy of 2.5) and we have so much fun! He loves grabbing the tiles and matching (doesn't matter who's card it is on!) and putting the tiles away. What a genius contraption the "card holder" is! He asks to play all the time and it's a game he can grow into once he's better at taking turns.
title: Toddler's First Game

author: zackandkaties mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2012
review_content: We were at thebeach this weekend with bad weather, unfortunately.  The kids were bored so I decided to pull out the board games.  My kids love love love the zingo game for the car so it thought I'd give this one a try.  My 4 year old was super excited but I wasnt sure how well he could play this.  My 7 year old is a reader and this game was rated too young for her.  After playing 20 minutes she became interested and joined in for another 30 minutes.  They both loved the way the holder zips back and forth.  My youngest revognizes letters so he was able to match words and quickly got the hang of it.  It held there attention long enough for the sun to come out so off to the beach we go!I highly recommend this game
title: Kept kids busy during foggy day at beach

author: Stacy Scott
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2018
review_content: I originally bought this for my 5 year old, who enjoys playing, but my 3 year old who has been slow to talk, absolutely LOVES this game and asks to play it all the time.  It's really helped her with talking since she has to say the name of the tiles she needs.  Can't say enough good things about this game.  My kids also really like handling the dispenser.
title: Great game!

author: JamB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2019
review_content: I bought this game for my nephews—3 & 5 years old! The love it! The game is adaptable, so both boys can enjoy it at their own level. Also, the boards are sturdy, so they can withstand the rough handling of the three year old—he’s a “Bam Bam”, and so far, so good.
title: Fun game—adaptable for different skill levels

author: Mother of 2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2014
review_content: Bought for my preschooler who was learning to read. Interesting game coz it makes her read the words. It is played like Bingo and the players take turn to push the zingo tile dispenser. The players then proceed to read the tiles matching their cards. However, the library of sight words is quite limited. After a while, it gets boring coz it is always the same few words. There are two sides to the game card, so could have been better if they have different difficulty levels of play. Otherwise, the quality of the game boards and the tile dispenser is very good and sturdy.
title: Interesting game for preschooler

author: InNormal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
review_content: I cannot say enough good things about Zingo games.  We have the Zingo sight words version and my six year old has been playing it for a couple years but my three year could only play with her with a great deal of assistance because the tiles show words only (no pictures).  This Zingo game showcases both words and pictures which is great for early readers and pre readers alike!Zingo is played like bingo although the object is to cover all your spaces first (there are play variations that do not require all spaces to be covered).  There are two sides to the cards-one is more competitive for older kids, the other side less competitive for younger kids.  There is nothing better than having a way for your kids to learn without them actually realizing they're learning.  This game does the trick.  It is fun for kids and adults alike & I truly believe that it improves reading skills.  This one is a winner!!!
title: LOVE Zingo games!!!!
verified: Style: ZingoVine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )

author: Forest Rose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2013
review_content: Over the past couple of weeks we have been having fun learning and practicing sight words with this game. This momma, loves fun learning games.  I am a firm believer that when we are having fun and enjoying whatever it may be, we are learning way more.The dreaded sight words or should I say "Trick Words" Sight words are words you cannot sound out usually, so after teaching your child to sound the word family words out and they get a good rhythm going on, now we have to throw a wrench in it with these crazy words...lol! Teaching sight words may try to trip you up, as a teacher, but don't let them keep you down.  Sight words, as you know are very important for children to learn, they make up over half of what we read, so you want your child to be strong and confident with these words, but it doesn't have to be boring and time consuming, make it fun with Zingo! Sight Words.I have one struggling reader and one fluent reader and they both enjoy this game.  My struggler, though I make sure to play this game mostly one on one to slow it down a bit, otherwise the fluent reader takes over and totally dominates the game, hence discouraging my struggler.  So beware, we want to make sure to give a little competiveness, but when it comes to learning make sure it is relaxed and fun.More about Zingo! Sight WordsTwo levels-One side of the game board is less competitive/Other Side more competitive.Developing Skills  Sight Word Recognition  Vocabulary  Matching  Observation and Perception  Concentration and Memory  Fine Motor Skills and Coordination  Following Instructions  Taking Turns  Winning and LosingThings we love about ZingoThis game is a spin off of the very popular bingo game and we love bingo!  I love the Zingo Zinger and it works great, the girls had no problem sliding it or putting the tiles back in the slots...even my 3 year old could do it:-)  Yes my 3 year old plays too, she gets some help from momma in her corner, but she is really good at matching, even though she can't read, that's why I love the pictures and patterns for extra help for the early learners and the struggling readers.Who Should Play Zingo?This game is meant for Pre-K-1st grade, but my 2nd grader and 3 year old preschooler love it too. You can vary the game to match the level anyway you want to.The Various Ways We PlayFor my 3 year old, she matches the words and the pictures, without knowing what they say.For my 1st and 2nd graders, I have them close their eyes after they say the word and have them spell it or use it in a sentence.I plan on in the future having them maybe write the spelling/sentence on paper to get extra handwriting practice in too...Not every time though I still want to keep it fun.What We would ChangeThere are actually only 24 words, the game description says 72 tiles so you would assume that there are 72 different words, not so...hmm.  I would definitely say please add more words:-)Homeschool mom of 3Seeking Kingdom First
title: Love to Learn

author: Liz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2020
review_content: I have a 4 year old boy with a short attention span. He loves this game and doesn't get bored with it. It was easy for him to learn how to play. I also think the materials are very sturdy. I would definitely recommend.
title: My 4 year old son loves this game

author: Amy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2017
review_content: Great for my 3yo!  We love the smoothness of how the pieces slide out of the dispenser, and how they pop in when you put them back in the top!  All the pieces are so sturdy as well, and the texture of the plastic feels great on my fingertips.  I did create my own cards (mirroring the original) so I could have just the word and not the picture on the board, inspiring my son to read some also.
title: Great for my 3yo

author: Donna W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2020
review_content: I bought this for my 4 yr old grandson and he loved it! We played it multiple times everyday during my visit. High quality, educational and fun!!
title: Highly recommended by my 4 year old grandson!

author: Lortega
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2016
review_content: What a great way to learn and have fun.  I'm a retired school teacher and I use this w/ my 5 & 7 year old.  My 7 year old struggles with ADHD, and very few things keep his attention, but he really likes this.  Now mind you, after about 3 times playing this, he's done for the day, but very few things keep his attention this long!  He struggles in school so this is a great way for him to learn his sight words, and my 5 year old is learning and getting ready for Kinder in the fall!
title: great for ADHD kids, too!

author: yaniv
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2019
review_content: Bought this as a gift for a 5 year old and she loves itOpened it immediately and started playingI read the mixed reviews, I honestly think this is a simple fun educational gameIt does the job
title: Great game

author: Sara
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2015
review_content: I have never played the original Zingo, but my kids received this  as a gift 3years ago and it has remained my son's favorite this  whole time (ages 2 to 5).At age 2 I used it to introduce the numbers though I would count them for him.  He loved the tactile feel of the yellow chips. Now at age 5 we can play the game as "equals" as he practices speed and fairness as well as the concept of addition.I love the clean up for this game. It contains many of the yellow chips but after use they skip right back into the main red game structure.  You slide them in a little slot and the structure somehow pulls them in once about half way in.  This "pulling in" is fun for the kids so mom doesn't get left to do it. It also helped my son with his fine motor skills,which were slightly behind and he preferred not to practice. In fact he played with the chips so much, putting them away and sliding them back out the bottom even when we weren't playing, that I worried he would wear the game out. I let him anyhow and three years later it remains good as new.
title: The family favorite

author: A. Leach
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2012
review_content: I recently was asked to review  this game for ThinkFun. Although my own kids are too old for this game, I am a Math specialist and work with teachers and students k-12. This game is a great alternative to practicing sight words instead of just flash cards!!  As a parent, I wish the game was around for my kids. It would've made learning sight words more fun and engaging! The game is perfect for Kindergarten and first grade students that have been introduced to sight words. The slider was definitely one of the things the kids liked best. It is nice that the game is random, allowing student to play together in friendly competition. The game will need replacement decks because kids will want to continue to play this game over and over with new words.
title: Great Way to Practice Sight Words

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2016
review_content: Several years ago I played this game with a 4 yrs old girl I was babysitting with and she would play it many times before moving on to another activity. When my grandson turned 4 I bought it for him and he is crazy about it too! First we just looked at each tile after sliding them out to work on recognition. Then taking turns we put the tiles on our cards until the card was all filled up, working on word recognition out loud. Eventually we will start playing bingo but for now this is a fun way to play that's not competitive. He sticks with this a surprising amount of time. The design of the slider is excellent and because the pieces are tiles there are no little balls escaping like with traditional bingo! The box is unbelievably sturdy and unlike flimsy board game boxes this will keep the game intact for years. I can't wait for his little brother to get big enough to play with us! Although the game says it's for 2-6 players, I think it could be a fun solitaire game too!
title: Fun Family Game for 4 yrs and up!

author: polly podgorski
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2020
review_content: My grandchildren received this game as a gift several years ago.  My grandson and granddaughter both LOVE this game and it is one that they are both eager to choose to play.  I highly recommend it!!!!!
title: Perfect gift!!

author: toysastoolsdotcc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2012
review_content: Sight Words: Evidence that English is REALLY HardSome words don't have any logic to them.  Those always made me mad but I have memorized them.  To my dismay, my kids have not.  I now know that they are called sight words.  Said is sed not sade.  Who is hoo and not wa hoe.  Now that I understand what sight words are, I feel good that I get to play Zingo! Sight Words with Number 2 Son who is learning how to read now and he's pretty good at it.  However, since sight words have little logic to them and this new Zingo game is good news indeed!  That is, because I can fairly say with confidence having studied more than three other languages, English is a really is a tough language to learn.  If kids or immigrants have a hard time learning to read English, it's not their fault.  Blame Brittania.We have owned and played   ThinkFun Zingo           and   ThinkFun Zingo 1-2-3           possibly hundreds of times (no kidding, Number 2 is crazy about Zingo) but for Zingo! Sight Words, I decided to consult an expert because I honestly don't know how kids are taught sight words. "Oh, I love Zingo," said Alison Berkley, one of my favorite education experts who is a true toy lover.  She owns many bingo games and but to Alison, Zingo! Sight Words really stands out. "It's a great game for kids because they like the tile things, [they] like clicking it back and forth!  It's really cool," she said.  "They like shoving the tiles back and forth when they're done. The boards are really colorful and engaging."Alison really likes that the boards have some sort of graphic to help kids distinguish between the words, especially when they look similar to each other.  (ie. there or three)  You might be wondering how they confused they could become but I've been watching my children closely and not only do they get confused but so do I!  Alison is right, the different images that ThinkFun creates for the words do help the children get used to the differences.  But then that worried me a little?  Is that a good thing? Shouldn't they be reading those words? Matching Words Requires Reading Words But Images Can HelpAlison said that we use images to teach vocabulary.  "You hold up a cup and you say cup.  When you're teaching new words, that's always kind of what we do," Alison explained.  "You're teaching them the meaning of that word and if it's concrete, like a number, you can show it."Then Alison showed me what the clear difference was from Zingo! Sight Words and other Bingo Vocab games.  "The other Bingos that I have have big pictures and tiny little letters on the tile boards as well as the tiles.  So there... they're just matching pictures," she said.  But for Zingo! Sight Words, it's different. "You are asking them to read the word on the tile and then look at their board, so they are reading first and then matching second." Finding New Ways to Learn?You are right Alison.  My kids ARE reading first and matching second, I LOVE THAT!!!!  Goodness, is there a Zingo! SAT Verbal Game?  I'm serious!  Wouldn't that be effective?  I am really trying to be more open-minded about learning reading and improving vocabulary.  I even found this book that used cartoons to help expand one's SAT Vocab list.  Wish I had this book back then!  ThinkFun, as usual, is doing something wildly creative with fun and learning and to kids,...well, I think all they see is the fun.  (which is why they learn it so fast!) Make it Work for Your FamilySpeaking of fun, this game is really a blast, especially for the little ones.  However, it can be more fun for the ones who might have a winner-loser anxiety IF you take turns and not let it be competitive.  (One person uses the Zinger at a time, if you have the word and matching tile, keep it, if not, give it out or push it back into the Zinger.)  Alternatively, you can be like Number 1 Son and make it much harder.  Just use more cards per game!  You can play against a little one if you use two cards and he uses just one. Use post it notes to cover up some words if you only want to use half a card.  There are lots of tiles in the Zinger so one adult and one kid can play this way without the adult falling asleep on the child because they purposely went slower to give the child a bit of a chance.Lastly, as those of us in New York and New Jersey and other affected areas deal with the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, I think back to those first days where many of us suffered from what might be called Cabin Fever.  To be honest, I don't know if it was Cabin Fever that my family suffered.  Looking out of the window was frightening and we weren't exactly "bored."  Each time we turned on the T.V., (because we were lucky that we never lost power) the news grew worse and worse.  And I have to say that while this family had SO MANY GAMES here (can't hide this fact), the best games for us at the time had to be the ones that made you laugh.  We really needed to laugh.  This game helped us entertain each other.  Sure this is a tool to increase sight word recognition and it is really good at that but you can't underestimate the fun factor.  It's just as strong here and that is Zingo's gift.
title: Learning is Easy When It's Fun!

author: Katie C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2018
review_content: My kids (3&5) love this game.  It’s easy to play and the rules are simple.  I was a little worried about the tiles being everywhere, but there are enough repeats that if we lose one or two the game will still work fine!

author: Narjah Stewart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2014
review_content: Your kids won't even know they're learning while playing this simple yet ingenious word building game. We love to play games together as a family and I'm all for including some education in the mix. Why not? I was given this game to review and give my honest feedback. I'm doing just that. My girls actually really like playing this game and so do I. This version of the game is an awesome word building exercise and it's perfect for ages 5 and up, though my 4 year old plays with us so she can learn along the way as well.The concept is so simple it makes one say, "why didn't I think of that". After shaming myself I get over it and I'm just plum happy that at least someone thought of it. The initial reaction to the game is one of, this may be a little fun...ok. Then when you start to play, it's just as addictive as a bingo game at the local fair without having to smooth talk the announcer. I felt like an old woman yelling for more chips.It's easy enough to have fun at and challenging enough to exercise you and your little ones brains. Get yours!

author: Mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2016
review_content: I bought this for my two year old. She was a little young for it then, but every now again I take it out to see if she is ready. title: Great Game for Reading Skill Development

author: GadgetFamily
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2016
review_content: Zingo is the perfect game for our family because of its wide appeal and flexibility in play.  Unlike many of the games we play, our whole family actually enjoys playing it!  Our youngest player (2) is able to match the pictures to the card without difficulty, while our readers are able to also match the words.  For the older kids, we use the red side of the playing cards, which increases the challenge slightly since those items are less available.  This gives the younger kids a fair chance to win, even without the older players having to tip the game in their favor.The tile dispensing "machine" is a huge hit with all of our kids!  We play a fairly casual game with the machine rotating from player to player, so they can each experience the thrill on a regular basis. (ha ha)  This helps keep our younger players engaged more, since they know the machine will be coming around to them soon.  When a tile or tiles is/are left unused, there are slots that you can slip the tiles into at the top of the machine.  They kids love inserting the superfluous tiles almost as much as dispensing them!The one thing I wish there was a way to improve is the shape of the tiles and the corresponding openings in dispenser.  The tiles have a very subtle rounding at the top and are squared at the bottom, so that (theoretically) they always face the right way when dispensed.  This is excellent and important, BUT it is a bit of a nuisance at the end of game play to get all the tiles facing the right way (and mixed up) to re-insertion into the dispenser.  The top and bottom of the tiles are not distinct enough to simply have them fall into place, which would be nice.  I was trying to figure out what shape would actually work better for this and wondered if maybe something with more dramatic differences in the top and bottom would be good, so that they could just be lined up by touch, rather than having to do them one by one.  (Like more of a pointed top and wide rounded bottom?)  Still, the cleanup/reloading of dispenser part is just another way to keep the kids active and engaged and it works fine for us.Zingo is such an awesome game for the whole family and I love that it integrates learning into our game time...those are always my favorite games as it is so much fun to watch the kids having a blast and know that they are subconsciously picking up sight words, even at 2 yrs of age!
title: Clever & fun! Love that we can sort of customize play so the playing field is level for a range of ages!

It has helped with the older one recognizing 6 and 9 and different between those two, plus his other numbers.

author: Happy in VT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2013
review_content: ThinkFun donated Zingo Sight Words to the first grade class in our school to try.  Another teacher in the building has a number of ThinkFun games in her class and for her family and recommended we try it out.  It has been a lot of fun!  The kids really loved the "sliding thing" (in their words) and loved that everyone got a turn.  A number of the kids pointed out they liked the easier and harder sides to the cards so it could be played at the level they were comfortable with.  Their only complaint was that shouting out made it a bit confusing.  I think this is a practice that can be modified.  Overall, great game from the kids' point of view and from a teacher's perspective looking for ways to reinforce sight words.
title: Review Made Fun!

author: Dana M Triana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2014
review_content: This fast-paced version of Bingo with an educational twist was truly a delight to our family. We love playing games together and never miss our weekly scheduled family game night. Board games always top our birthday and holiday lists and we are always on the hunt for a new game to play. Zingo! Word Builder was the perfect educational and fun game for my kindergartener.This fun, interactive game encouraged my son to review basic sight words as well as learn new words by building them himself. He loved sliding the Zinger and quickly grabbing the letter tiles before I could. He had a blast building three letter words and reading them aloud. As a former kindergarten teacher, I liked the game's goals of improving spelling, word recognition, letter sounds and consonants/vowels. With two levels of play, it’s a great game for both beginner and more advanced readers. This is definitely a game that will aid him in kindergarten and beyond. Zingo! Word Builder is a great game to pass on to his sister and for me to use in the classroom.  Perfect for the recommended ages 5-8.  Look for our full review on Jerseyfamilyfun DOT com by searching "Zingo World Builder".In full disclosure we were provided with Zingo! Word Builder to make this review possible. As always our opinions are 100% our own.
title: Word Building Fun for Beginning Readers

author: newtoamazon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2020
review_content: Love this game so much! Such a good family game, even my 2 year old understands and can play
title: Must buy

author: CuteMonsterDad
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2012
review_content: ThinkFun provided my site, CuteMonster.com a review copy of the game.  My opinions are my own.  The following is an excerpt of my review of the game:Zingo! Sight Words takes the game premise of Bingo, replaces the numbers, and incorporates sight words which are words most frequently used in the English language. Mastering sight words creates fluent readers.Based on my own official game testers aka my children, Zingo! Sight Words offers up challenging yet accessible game play that encourages older kids to help their younger siblings learn to read. My 1st grader, to my surprise, often helped his kid sister navigate through each of her turns. Especially if he was given the responsibility of being the dealer. Dare I say that Zingo! Sight Words may well be a means to a temporary ceasefire in the sibling rivalry wars. Peace and cooperation through board games. Who knew?
title: ThinkFun's  Zingo! Sight Words

author: William Spence
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2013
review_content: Learning those basic sight words is a vital part of helping kids become fluent readers.  Zingo! Sight Words is such a fun way for kids to learn and review the basic sight words! My kids {ages 3 years, 4 years, and 2nd grade} all enjoyed it for MANY reasons; from playing with letters to learning and reviewing sight words.As an advocate for struggling readers,I think the concept is brilliant.  The visual pictures {visual learners}, calling out of words {auditory learners}, and physical movement {kinesthetic learners} makes the game multi-sensory: a perfect match for struggling readers!
title: Great for Struggling Readers

author: Momof2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2012
review_content: My 5 and 8 year old are big Zingo! fans, so when Zingo! Sight Words came out I was excited to add it to our game collection with the hopes it would replace flash cards. Problem solved! My kids already love the Bingo game concept, so were agreeable from the start. They play and learn together with this game. My youngest is already recognizing essential words, and my oldest is reinforcing his reading development. Plus the slider is a hit, and it stores the tiles after use for easy clean up. This game is a wonderful tool to help kids learn and master sight words. It beats out flash cards anyday! At least in my house.

review_content: My little one loves to play Zingo! Sight Words. This game is fun for the whole family and it really makes children feel proud when they are able to fill their card. The concept is simple: Use the {super fun} slider to dispense tiles, match the tiles with the words on your card, and the first one to fill their card wins! No batteries needed and the tiles store inside of the Zingo tile dispenser. My little one actually likes this game a lot and he's not one for flashcards--two thumbs up from us :) Tiffany & Noah.

review_content: Disclosure: I received a free version of this game from ThinkFun in return for writing an honest review. author: Rachael P.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2016
review_content: This was pretty fun for my 7 year-old and almost 9 year-old. You have bingo sheets and then use the red container to reveal the "chips." Tod o that you push down on the top and then players call out if they have a match. Most kids like bingo so essentially that's what makes this game a hit - kids can't wait to finish first with all the matches. What's a little tricky playing all together is the fact that you call out what you see and that can create some tensions. Also everyone (kids) usually want a turn pushing down the red thingy and that makes it hard to position it so everyone can see what chips come out. You could take turns and each game only 1 person does it, like a dealer. But if you have a bunch of kids that means you're playing the game for awhile - which may be fine or start to drag! I also thought it was an odd choice to make the chips not square shaped, so that it's a little wonky lining them up to fit properly in the red box. Seemed like it would have been a lot easier to make them all square so you don't have to take the time to line them up properly to fit smoothly. Overall it's fun and kids enjoyed it but isn't a top fav for our family.
title: This was pretty fun for my 7 year-old and almost 9 year-old

author: S. K. Harrell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2015
review_content: This version of Bingo Zingo is a great step up from the previous games in this line for your kids. It encourages spelling and creativity. Adults have to step it back a bit to give kids a chance to spell, but it's still a fun and thoughtful game for the family.

author: KM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2020

author: Echo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2012
review_content: I was excited when I received this awesome product from ThinkFun to review with my gifted and talented students. I have used and loved the original Zingo game with my students for years. I tried this game with my Kindergarten students and they had a great time! Finally a fun way to practice reading and quickly recognizing sight words. Having two sides helps differentiate for my students, allowing some students to have the more challenging cards. I was thrilled when I saw the improvements to the Zinger that allows students to reload the tiles. Much faster cleanup! I appreciate that ThinkFun is always looking for ways to improve their products
title: Fun way to practice sight words!

author: drsra
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2016

author: M. Shaw
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2011
review_content: While the game itself is fun, I am very disappointed in the quality.  As others have mentioned, the tiles frequently stick together (some of ours were even slightly bent upon opening). Additionally it's very difficult to slide the tiles back into the top slot.  I purchased this game in a store for slightly more than what amazon offers it for.  If it weren't for the learning potential of the game, I would be inclined to say it wasn't worth the money.
title: Less than desirable quality

author: AdamsFamilyReviews
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2012
review_content: My kids are 3.5 years old and almost 6 years old. They both enjoyed playing Zingo Sight Words. Even though my youngest isn't really reading yet, she was able to match the words and play along. My oldest has been reading for quite a while. I think this game helped build her confidence in her abilities. Zingo Sight Words is a fun family game.
title: AdamsFmReviews

title: A win

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2016
review_content: My 2 year old loves this game! He's still a bit young to really get it, but he still loves it, the option to put the tikes back on the top works great!
title: Great family game!
verified: Style: ZingoVine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )

author: Jennifer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2012
review_content: I received this game from ThinkFun for free as part of their BrainLab program. I teach a 1st/2nd grade combo and use many of their games (which I have purchased) for logic, problem solving and teamwork skills.The game is easy to play with simple rules and only a few parts. A typical game in my classroom took 5-10 minutes to play, making it a great center activity or activity for filling a few minutes. We even set it up on the ELMO and played girls against boys as a whole class.I liked that it had 2 levels. My 1st grade students (more gifted on average and strong readers) played the challenging level. Overall it was easy for them, would have been better for them in pre-K or K but I think it would work well in an average 1st grade classroom.
title: Great for the classroom

author: primeuser
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2020
review_content: Gave it as a gift. It was loved.
title: Good Product

author: Kelly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2016
review_content: No visual attraction. I think those larger boards with color cards are much better.
title: It's okay but wouldn't buy it again

author: Jenny
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2015
review_content: I wish I loved this game but its more about a game of counting and reading the word corresponding to a number. It would work better if the numbers were on the cards and the objects to count on the tiles, same goes with the addition side. This way you can count the objects on the tiles and then try to match the number. My 3 year old can do the addition side because all you do is count the objects and it really is no different than the counting side. Again, the game would have worked better if the addition side showed numbers instead of objects.
title: Numbers should be on the cards!!

author: Jeanette Wood
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2014
review_content: This was a great game for my boys, both beginning readers!ThinkFun asked me if I'd like to review a few of their products. I am so glad I said yes! This game had both boys fully engaged, laughing, and learning! Even older children and toddlers walking by wanted to be part of the fun! My boys played at a fast pace however, it could be played slower for younger learners since the pace is set by the players. Zingo would be a great alternative for children not yet ready for Scrabble.
title: Learning and Laughing!

author: StarTraci
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2012
review_content: We play Zingo almost every night. I got it to practice sight words with my 5 year old daughter but my older son uses it in his speech class. He loves the game and it is a way for both of them to have fun while working on each of their goals. How happy does that make me!!!
title: Zingo is awesome!

review_content: We received this Zingo! game this week - and my kindergartener has not stopped asking to play again (and again, and again!). The slider is really cool, and works well each time.  The kids both (yes, the 9 year old was happily playing along) had a great time using it.  I love that there are six double-sided cards, so that we can all play and also mix it up.  I would definitely recommend this for your young one.
title: Educational and FUN!

It moves quickly and thanks to printing on both sides of the tiles, it is very easy to clean up.  Excellent for a school resource.

review_content: Zingo! Word Builder builds your children’s word skills- three letters at time! date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2013
review_content: I am a first grade teacher and I LOVE this game! I love this game because it is interactive and it supports high student engagement.  Definitely a "must-have" for a classroom with emergent to early readers!
title: My first graders love it!

author: T. Hewlett
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2012
review_content: We have a lot of the ThinkFun games and we love every one of them, but the sight word Zingo! just might be my favorite. I home school my kids and my boys ages 6 and 4 love to play games...but don't love to read as much as my girl does. This game has been huge in helping both of them recognize sight words not only in the game but in reading their books as well. They are much more willing to read when they don't get frustrated over these words that don't "sound out" like other words. The game can be played together at both of their skill levels, so that makes it really nice. I also love that they can play it independently without my help and supervision when I need to be working with their older sister or taking care of the baby. I know that they are learning and having fun at the same time and as a mom, that is huge! I would recommend this game to anyone with a preschooler through second or third grade. Especially those that have a frustrated reader or two like myself!
title: My kids are loving Zingo!

author: Jess McB
date_of_review: Reviewed in Canada on May 29, 2019
review_content: My daughter is 5 and I was hopeful this would encourage her literacy skills.  The tiles are quite durable and the text is a great size print.  While she isn't currently able to read all the words, we are working on them together and each time we play she is able to identify more.  The only issue we have come across is that on occasion when sliding the tile dispenser it has jammed.  Nothing too serious, but definitely required an adult to get the stuck tiles out.  I think it happens when you are not on a firm, level surface ( ie- playing on the carpeted floor)Would recommend!

date_of_review: Reviewed in Canada on August 18, 2019
review_content: The sight words were not a good representation of elementary sight word lists that are commonly used is early education and there were not a lot. The machine that stored the words that the children slide is well made and durable, it just needs more words.

date_of_review: Reviewed in Canada on October 29, 2020
review_content: This is a great game for children learning to read..........word recognition........phonics.........spelling..........comprehension and the challenge to win!Start out easy to build interest and keenest in the game in time you can add more challenges to the game.  The child/ren learn with laughter and cheers by sounding the word  or spelling the word or saying it in a sentence.  A fun way to learn and would help children that might need extra help to achieve their dream to read.

Además se practican palabras básicas de inglés . Mis hijos lo jugaron mucho cuando eran niños, en esta ocasión lo compré para regalar ! Me pareció fantástico !

date_of_review: Reviewed in Canada on January 30, 2017
review_content: It's our favorite math centre in our Kindergarten class. The children learn to recognize numerals, quantity, one to one matching when counting, and some estimation skills. I highly recommend this game for home or school use.

I can see potential to customise it also by making new bingo boards (and even experimenting with cutting extra letters  or letter combinations out of card or plastic although this is more doubtful as it is engineered to deliver tiles of precise thickness.)
