author: MM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 25, 2012
review_content: I am really impressed with this game. It's very simple so children can easily understand the rules.Easy to operate the zinger machine - although my 3 year old kept trying to load the numbers in the wrong way round but they did still come out fine.Good quality and well made, it seems very durable.My 3 year old (nearly 4) loves maths and numbers so he was very excited with this game, and I like it as it will help him learn, and is also fun.It does not need any batteries, and has plenty of cards so up to 6 people can play at once. When you turn the card round there is another version on the other side, about addition, so if your child wants a bit more of a challenge they can play the addition version instead of the normal.Overall I found it really good - for both education and fun so we are very happy with it.I had not heard of 'thinkfun' before, but I will be having a look what else they have got. This game seems like good value.I would recommend it for children around 4 years old, as the box states, or 3.5 would probably be okay. We had to keep it out the way of our 2 year old as it is not really suitable for him and it does have small pieces (the number cards) which I wouldn't say are a real choking issue but he would probably throw them all round the house. However when he is a bit bigger it is something that children could play together by themselves as the zinger machine is very easy to use
title: Brilliant maths game

author: Charlie-CJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 16, 2012
review_content: There's two versions of Zingo aimed at Primary school youngsters, one is 'Zingo Bingo' that has images and words that you can match up with those on the card, and the other is this 'Zingo Number 1-2-3 Bingo' that requires the kids to count up the number of objects in the Bingo card spaces and match it with the number on the tile as it comes out of the red Zingo machine. The Zingo Bingo cards have the number of objects shown and the number written in words, so it helps with counting and reading. The game is for children aged 4 and up, and for 2 to 6 players. Inside the box are six double-sided Zingo Cards, 72 Double-Sided Tiles, and the red Zingo! Zinger machine to issue the cards out one by one. The game has two levels of play (an easier side and a harder side if you turn the card over), plus there's 'easy cleanup' as the tiles just slot back into the Zingo machine after use.I got this game for my nephew (aged 5) and he enjoys playing it occasionally with me and his mum and dad. Sadly his other Brothers are aged 3 and 12, so they aren't that interested in the game being a bit too young and a bit too old - in fact the simpler picture version of Zingo Bingo (the   Zingo Bingo Game          ) is far better suited to younger kids, as you can just match the pictures, so check that game out as well. Still Zingo Number Bingo 1-2-3 is a well thought out educational game, and every preteen kid seems to love Bingo, so overall it's hit and we'll give it 5*.
title: This is the numbers counting version of Zingo - Good fun for Primary school kids

author: D. Thurgood
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 23, 2012
review_content: This is a fab little game for kids that will help them with their maths understanding. I have a 2 yr old, a 4 yr old and a 7 yr old,  and they all loved playing it at the same time, albeit for different reasons. The game is bingo-based (hence the name) and comprises a number generator (no batteries here! Whoo-hoo!) with numbered tiles and a set of bingo cards. These are double sided and each one has an easy level side and a more difficult level side. This is great as it means the game really can be played by kids of differing abilities simultaneously.The number 'machine' is nicely built but sadly not brilliantly designed. You load the tiles in the top (they must go in the right orientation, but the channels in which they sit are not snug fitting enough to prevent them being placed in the wrong way around. Fail.) and then slide the housing across the base and back again, and hey presto,  2 tiles are neatly deposited. The kids who shout out their values first get to place them on their cards a la regular bingo. The 'numbers' on the cards are more tricky - on the easy cards they are written in words, not number as well as represented pictorially. The harder side actually has no writing on at all and shows the number only as a sum that the kid must decipher. This is surprisingly tricky even for an adult when the pressure is on and the bingo red cloud has come down.Overall I really like this game - my kids love it too. I've only given it 4 stars as I don't think it's very well designed. The tile hopper lid  fits correctly only one way round, but can very easily be forced on the wrong way round which will ultimately cause it to break. This is poor for a kid's game. In addition, during game play, if a tile is taken by any player, then it is 'posted' back into the hopper through two small slits. This is very fiddly and interrupts game play. You can choose not to do this, but then you have tiles flapping around all over the place, which you have to load back into the hopper afterwards. The 'mechanics' of this game could be better.
title: learning can be fun... no, really!

author: Clare
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 19, 2012
review_content: I played this with three 4 and 5 year olds and they LOVED it! This is a bingo game with 6 game boards. On one side you have pictures to count and the words to read, although obviously we weren't quite at the stage of reading them yet. The other side has addition sums in the form of two groups of pictures. The fun part that the kids really enjoyed was the Zingo tile holder. They slide the tower forwards and then back and two tiles are revealed. The child to work out if they need one of those numbers calls out the number and takes the tile. If one of the tiles isn't needed then the tile gets posted back into a slot at the top. The winner is the first to complete their board and shout Zingo.I really like that there are sums on one side so that you can extend your child's learning.The one 2 things that for me are slight downsides are that the pictures are quite small and sometimes the children struggled with the one to one correspondance of pointing to the pictures as they said the numbers but that was partly just the developmental stage they're at anyway and the tiles have to be put in a certain way. When the kids played on their own they put the tiles in so some went in backwards. They fit in but when they reach the bottom they don't come out when you slide.I would definately recommend this game if you are working on maths skills.
title: A resounding Success!

author: Lunar Shine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 27, 2012
review_content: Zingo 1-2-3 is a great game to play for all ages, even a Grandparent like myself.  It is based on the good old game of Bingo.  The game contains 6 double sided cards, 72 double sided yellow plastic tiles which display numbers 0 - 12  and  a red plastic container which dispensers these tiles.  The tiles are easy to load and the dispenser is easy to use.  I would say however that the double sided cards are not very durable, hence my low mark, they can bend quite easily and would have been much better if they were a little thicker cardboard. The Green side of the card shows graphics and the corresponding written number - this is where I think the games falls down a little.  Maybe instead of displaying the 'written' number, the actual number should be shown then, this would help the younger children who couldn't yet read.  On the Red side easy sums are displayed by small graphics with a plus or minus sign.The game shows the age of 4 and my Grandson is not quite 3.1/2, and very smart, but isn't able to read yet; however we played the game together and I helped him with the counting and reading and he thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.  He recognises actual numbers, but could't read the actual word of the number.Overall I think this game is a winner and good value for money.
title: Great Fun Educational Toy

author: CJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 18, 2012
review_content: Zingo! is a well made, simple game ideally suited for younger children.  Each player has a Zingo (bingo) card, with each square on it containing a written number plus different items in that quantity.  This encourages counting and reading when the player is trying to identify which numbers they need.The included dispenser is loaded up with numbers and then a simple sliding mechanism reveals two numbers each turn.  If you have one of these numbers on your card, shout out first!  On the other side of the cards the principle is the same but this time a sum is presented rather than just a straightforward number, so players have to do the maths in order to work out what they require and then call out when they see the correct number.It all works pretty well and as I mentioned before, the parts are well made and sturdy.  The inclusion of both regular numbers and simple sums gives the game some growth and obviously, it's educational aspect is great.Like any such game, interest will come and go, but as it's simple to play and good fun too, Zingo! is a thoroughly decent game for your kids to enjoy and learn from it too.
title: Bingo for kids.  With added sums.

author: Mrs. Bryony A. Shaw
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 14, 2012
review_content: I have been playing this with my 5 year old daughter. We both loved the tile dispenser, like magic how you slide it forward to reveal the numbers and then nice solid little posting slot to put them in again, very appealing. I was a little surprised that none of the cards have actual numbers on but an illustration of the number with the word written underneath. This initially meant my daughter found it very hard as she is new to reading and so was having to count everything. A few games down the line tho and she is getting much better at recognising the amounts and so I guess it is proving educationally beneficial from that point of view. She was very nearly put off completely though so maybe a starter set of cards with numbers on while they are getting the hang of it would be good.We don't play for long, 10/15 mins usually but she does ask for it 2/3 times a week and I don't mind playing as I know she won't want to play for hours. I think it's because she does have to work a bit that we don't play it longer but I think that's a positive really. As others have said its a shame the box couldn't be a bit smaller. All in all a nice little game tho, think we will have it around for a long time.
title: Nice little game, good for familiarising with numbers.

author: Stusie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 12, 2012
review_content: Designed for ages "4 and up", Zingo is a fun number bingo game for two to six players.  At the heart of the game is the "Zinger".  Load it up with number tiles and slide it back and forth to reveal the numbers.  Call out the numbers and the winner is the first person to fill their card.  Bingo!  The Zinger itself is robust and easy to fill - and it helps add a little bit of extra fun to what is otherwise a fairly traditional game.The number tiles are bright, clear platic pieces with the numbers clearly written on them in black.  For an extra twist, the Zingo cards have two sides, giving you two levels of play.  The green side has the numbers written in words, e.g., "Nine" and a supporting ilustration - in this example nine apples.  The red side is slightly harder and helps with adding on skills.  Rather than a number you simply get an illustrative sum, e.g., a picture of five cars followed by a plus sign and four more cars.We have lots of learning games, but this one has proven popular with the whole family.  We've played it several times after Sunday lunch with the children, parents and grandparents all gathered round.  Everyone likes bingo, or should I say Zingo?!
title: A fun family numbers game.

author: Easterchick
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 11, 2012
review_content: Thinkfun Zingo works uses the simple concept of Bingo and applying it to maths for younger children.  It has two levels; one with straightforward numbers, which my 5 1/2 year old found easy, and one which works on addition, which is a bit more complex (my daughter couldn't be persuaded to try it though!)It takes a few minutes to set up, and is a bit fiddly - little tiles need to be put into a holder the right way round (which my 3 year old didn't understand).  So probably this game needs some adult help.  Once set up it's simple to use.Once set up, the 'slider' slides out 2 tiles at a time, which personally I think is a bit of a design flaw - as a more able child can snatch them both while a less able child is still thinking!  It would be a lot better if you only got 1 tile at a time.Other things I'd like to see: cards for subtraction, and 'teen' numbers.The girls did enjoy the competitive element, and so did their grandparents!  All had a happy half hour playing this.  I can recommend it.
title: Ideal for all the family - kids and grandparents alike!

author: Puff of joy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 25, 2012
review_content: yes i know its yet another version of bingo but then again they are not the first and wont be the last to rehash this game and style.however that said i think this is rather a good version and worth the money if you have a young family and love to play traditional games and enjoy fitting in learning with playing.on first glance at opening the box my first thought was " here we go again more batteries needed" but no no batteries required, the number dispenser works just with a hand and a sliding motion, it also comes with 6 zingo boards to play with which is nice as often games only have four and with my family being five this was a nice addition.the boards come in two sides  one harder than the other, one has numbers with pictures of things such as fish and cakes in the right amount which is the easy side and side two has two amounts you need to add together before you can see which number you need making it much harder for when the little ones need pushing a little harder.good fast paced fun traditional family game.i would highly recommend this game
title: great family fun

author: My Name Is Prince
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 28, 2012
review_content: A neat little game this, and it's gone straight to number one in the house (oh, fickle children). There's a clever little number tile dispenser that reveals new tiles with a quick slide across and back (my son still thinks that's a bit magical) and players then call for and take tiles that they need to fill up their bingo-like card. The cards have two levels of difficulty; one side containing just numbers (written as words with pictures to illustrate) the other simple sums to arrive at the number required. The box states that the game is for kids of 4 and up but I would mention that my 4 year old is used to recognising numbers written as numbers rather than words. That means he has to count up the pictures on his card before he knows what numbers are on it making it a bit slow at first. On the plus side maybe this will help speed up reading recognition of numbers. That's the thing with this game, it feels like it really is aiding learning but with the thrill of bingo added!
title: Winning lines

author: EllyBlue
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 16, 2012
review_content: This came is an updated version of Bingo that helps chidren develop their mental dexterity with numbers. It consists of tough double sided cards, a set of tiles and a Zingo dispenser. The aim of the game is to cover the squares on the board with the tiles as they emerge, and the first one to cover all the squares on their board is the winner. You can mix it up a bit by having to cover just certain squares - in a cross shape for example, and I have levelled the playing field between my six year old and my eight year old, by getting one to do the "easy" side of the card which is just a question of counting/number recogntion and the other to do the harder side which requires addition skills too.This is a simple game, but good fun, and gets children to practice numeracy skills in a fun way. It would be useful for children from about age 3, and would be a real asset in a reception or key stage 1 classroom. Just goes to show that sometimes, the simplest ideas are the best.
title: Good fun and helps with numerical skills too

author: H. Pierce
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 13, 2012
review_content: My three year old daughter loves playing this game, and it has proved a hit with her friends as well...and, yes, even us adults have enjoyed playing! It is a fun way of encouraging your child to do some simple maths without them even realising that they are learning. It is suitable from about three years upwards. You will know if your child is ready for it based on their ability to recognise numbers. One of the best features is the fact that you can help to overcome age advantages by letting the youngest children use the digit cards, and the older children use the addition cards. This means that the game can be equally fun for all those playing, and can help to prevent the unfair advantage your older children may have over the younger ones.Overall, I highly recommend this from age 3 upwards. Fun for all the family, and educational too!
title: Great Fun!

author: Mr. M. A. Reed
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 17, 2012
review_content: For children of all ages, Zingo is a fairly exciting experience. My son, aged 7 - the only boy I know who got two toys with one go on THE GRABBER at the amusement arcade - loves it. With a  two-tier playing field, using numerals, addition, matching, and basic maths, it allows us to play, and of course for me to 'let' him win, as well as the number dispenser which he thinks is genius. When they get older, its one of those games you can let them play without worrying about it getting broken or boys getting hurt. It takes the two, sometimes mutually opposed aims of fun, and education, puts the two together and is simple, novel, and lots of fun. Giggles and laughter and sadly, the inevitable disappointment from the losers, are all swept away when the dispenser starts again, and we begin again, and he beats me again. Great fun.
title: Great fun

author: Rich
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 7, 2012
review_content: The manufacturers have attempted to bridge the gap between a fun game and an educational toy.  And by and large they've done it.  They've taken one of the oldest games around and added the tweaks necessary to engage today's youngsters.  The machine makes the revealing of the numbers more fun than simply pulling tiles from a bag.  And the matching exercises comes with small games to help children master the concepts of numbers and counting.  We've found it very popular in the age range for which it's intended; 4 and up.  And it works very well as a toy for children and parents to play together.  It might seem a little old fashioned as a concept these days, but I think it works very well.  Recommended,
title: Clever Twist on Traditional Game

author: P. Dhinsa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 15, 2012
review_content: I actually got this number recognition bingo style game for my four year old daughter.  She really loves it!  The way that the counters pop out of the dispenser makes it quite exciting and she has been counting the objects and matching the correct number.  Her eight and ten year old sisters have really enjoyed playing the game with her too.  There are more challenging cards where you add the two groups of objects together to find the total, and I think this is perfect for children in Reception or year One.  It is a family game that can be enjoyed by all, and I would highly recommend it.  The quality of the game is excellent.  Great for number recognition, counting and learning to take turns.
title: My children love this game

author: Andyboff66
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 26, 2012
review_content: In a World rife with electronic games, computers, i Pads and so on, where 8 year old kids play Angry Birds on their cellphone, it's so nice to see an old fashioned board game.A very simple take on Bingo, as others have said, this is a great way to make Maths fun for the little ones.It's well made, easily set up, safe for unsupervised play, but fun enough for parents and Grandparents to join in, without being bogged down with umpteen rules and game play options.Looks pretty durable, there's not exactly much you can break (except the card dispenser) and overall I gave it 4 stars.Inexpensive, educational, fun, and get's the family together, what's not to like?
title: Subliminal Learning Curve

author: shoemaker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 11, 2012
review_content: fun and educational,this is just right for my grandson Ben at 4 years old he is due to start school in september,and this game for sure will help to learn him is maths skills and he as fun to,what could be better,there are 6 zingo cards,72 number tiles and zingo zinger.the name of the game is to cover all your spaces with the tiles on your card,the cards have to sides 1 red and 1 green,the green side tells you the number eg 5,but the red side you need to add eg 1 fish and 4 fish are?so your little one starts to learn(bless) to add together.zingo is for 2 to 6 players and from 4 years and above comes complete with parents guide and i cant recommend it enough,thumbs up
title: fun and educational.

author: Kass
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 21, 2012
review_content: Zingo is a really neat, compact little game that is packed with fun and education for little ones. My girls are aged 4 and 6 and this seems to match their age and abilities well, my older daughter enjoying the game at all level s and indeed helping her sister out with her addition skills as we play.I'm really pleased to see how sturdily it has been made, so that it won't break after a few uses like so many other toys seem to.If you enjoy the simple fun of basic bingo, you will almost certainly enjoy the added fun that Zingo brings to a classic game. Recommended for all families with little ones ready to learn.
title: Educational bingo fun

author: Robert O. Davidson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 19, 2012
review_content: The book is intended to help parents develop their children's reading and counting skills. It could be used from about 3 years onwards and up to 7 or 8. The concept is fairly simple and loosely based on bingo. Children, playing with adult family members, have to match up tiles to fill in their challenge card. The first person with a full card shouts 'Zingo'. Children connect digits with images and text and also develop maths skills without realising it.A worthwhile purchase.
title: A useful fun game for developing reading and counting skills

author: Pompom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 15, 2012
review_content: Zingo is a great little game based on the familiar premise of bingo.  My 4 year old has really enjoyed it, albeit for limited lengths of time (his attention span isn't great!), and I am sure it will continue in use for years.  Zingo helps the learning skills of counting, number sense and patterns and relationships.  There are two levels of play, a simpler version with counting, and the slightly more advanced 'addition'.  The zinger card dispenser is a nice touch.  Highly recommended.
title: Numbers can be fun!

author: Tan y ddraig
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 19, 2012
review_content: My 6 and 7 yr old daughters (and I) absolutely love this game and being so small and compact they even brought it on our rather damp Summer camping trip to while away the hours. It is good simple fun that has a huge educational benefit and also gets the good old fashioned family interaction going, instead of them being stuck in a corner with their Nintendo's trying to get a giant mushroom to destroy Bowser's latest incarnation. Highly recommended.
title: Interactive, educational and fun

author: McColey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 21, 2012
review_content: This game has been played by my two daughters aged 6 and 7.  The girls particularly like the little number dispenser and have even used that to make up their own games.  With so many play variations, the girls have really enjoyed playing the different modes many times over.  It just proves that the simplest ideas still have a lot of attraction despite all the electronic gaming options available these days.
title: Hours of Zingo playtime

author: twinmama19
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 17, 2012
review_content: I've played this with my 3 year old son and it's been a great addition to his game time and is encouraging his learning about numbers. I personally like this game because it does not require batteries and is easy to play. We're currently using it to identify numbers but will build on to the addition bit as he gets older. A good value game with educational benefit as well.
title: Numbers bingo for kids

author: K. Wright
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 1, 2012
review_content: Zingo is a simple but fun bingo game for children aged around 3-5 who are beginning to recognise numbers by matching the clear number tiles to their bingo board. Slighly older children can also play the variation on the reverse side of the board where there are pictures in two sets with an addition sign. Whilst children can add these, they can also rely on counting, so I would have liked another board just with written addition questions to increase the challenge level again for 5-7 year olds.The Zingo machine itself is a great idea as it makes revealing the bingo numbers, a fun part of the game. The numbers are stacked in 2 equal piles and then the lid covers over them. By simply sliding the machine forward 2 numbers are revealed for the taking. However there is an issue with the design as the numbers must be placed in the same direction with the curved part of the number at the top. This wouldn't be a problem if the numbers fit snuggly in the machine but the machine gap is large enough to have numbers inserted upside-down. I also found posting back any unused tiles through the top of the Zinger is a bit fiddly. Overall it is a good educational game for young children but could have been better with a little more thought on the design.
title: Simple Bingo Game with design flaw

author: M & M
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 24, 2012
review_content: Zingo! 1-2-3 is a little bit twisted children's version of regular bingo game. It provides hours of fun for the whole family and it's educational at the same time. It is recommended for ages 4+ but 2 of our kids: 6 and 16 year old enjoyed it a lot and since the game arrived they can't stop playing Zingo!.The box contains "zinger" - dealing machine with 72 number tiles and 6 double sided cards that 6 people can play at the same time or even 7 if the dealer is not one of the players as well.Be aware that the product description is a little bit confusing - this Zingo! edition does not contain double sided tiles with graphics (as seen on second image "how to play"), it has double sided tiles with the same numbers on both sides and 6 double sided cards: green side with "counting" and red side with "addition" so you can decide which side to use for the game, depending on the child's level.  (I have uploaded image of the actual tiles and cards.)The green side of the cards has numbers in pictures and written as a word, for instance picture of 3 balloons and written "three" underneath.The red side is a little more difficult, children must do some maths / additions to figure out the numbers, for instance picture of 5 hearts + 1 heart.The only disadvantage I can find is the box, which could be half smaller. My daughter's wardrobe is already filled many game & puzzle boxes so it would be absolutely useful if the box wasn't over sized.
title: Educational game that provides hours of fun for the whole family.

author: Bellyobibblybob
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 24, 2012
review_content: We loved this game - really easy to set up and use and great for supporting number recognition and early addition skills.Good for 2,3 or 4 players, solid and hard wearing too.Highly recommended.
title: What fun!

author: Mrs. N. C. Kelly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 17, 2012
review_content: A nice little game that gets the children thinking but without making them realise what they are learning.  Fun and bright.  Weel worth the money.
title: nice little way tp learn

author: TSegurado
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 9, 2012
review_content: Bingo for kids. This is a very fun game and highly interactive! The numbers are always paired up with figures so the child can associate for example the number 4 to four butterflies which always come out together. Children get interested quickly and spend hours playing it. You could get them some prize like sweets or something to make it even more fun!
title: Perfect for little learners!
